title: jeremy corbyn michel barnier brussels brexit
story: The Labour leaders aide had to make an urgent appeal for cash after realising no one was able to pay for the cab in Brussels this afternoon.Mr Corbyn was left waiting outside EU headquarters as his staff had a whip-round - and risked being late for his meeting with top eurocrat Michel Barnier.He told Mr Barnier, the EUs Brexit envoy, that Britain cant quit the EU without a trade deal lined up.The talks are a fresh bid to undermine the official Brexit negotiations being carried out by Theresa May.Mr Corbyn drew up at the office of the European Commission in a taxi with Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer.But the driver apparently refused to go in to the buildings vehicle entrance until he was paid - and he didnt accept cards.A Labour aide was heard asking, Does anyone have any euros?Mr Corbyns right-hand man Seumas Milne laughed as another aide stepped in to provide the money needed.Labours fresh attempt to sideline Mrs May in Brussels comes after Labour opened the door to a second referendum on Brexit at their party conference this week.Mr Corbyn took Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer with him on the trip to Brussels today.Speaking after the meting, he said: Weve had an interesting, useful discussion with Mr Barnier.We have set out the views of the Labour Party surrounding Brexit following the conference speeches made by Keir Starmer and myself.We are obviously not negotiating. We are not in government, we are the opposition. But he was interested to know what our views are and the six tests we have laid down by which we will hold our government in future.The Labour boss refused to say whether Mr Barnier had backed Labours plan - which would keep the UK in the European customs union - over Theresa Mays.He said it would be going over the line to press the eurocrat on his views.Mr Corbyn said last night: “Crashing out of Europe with no deal risks being a national disaster.That is why I’m meeting EU officials today, and I will be urging them to do all they can to avoid a No Deal outcome, which would be so damaging to jobs and living standards in both the UK and EU countries.”The PM has repeatedly insisted that Britain must be prepared for a No Deal scenario.Otherwise the EU will be able to force us to accept whatever deal they want.Mr Corbyn is keen to keep Britain in the European customs union after Brexit - even though that would stop us cutting trade deals around the world.And at the Labour conference, activists voted for a new policy which could see the party backing a second referendum  Mrs May refuses to hold a General Election.Mr Barnier has previously met with a string of pro-EU politicians from Britain, who have lobbied him not to accept the PMs Brexit plans.

title: renters abandon tories housing
story: A new survey of the 60 tighest constituency battlefields shows barely a quarter – 28% - of the key voting group living in them now back Theresa May’s party. Half – 50% - now plan to vote for Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour party instead.The findings – by pollsters Number Cruncher Politics for the housing charity Shelter – suggest soaring rents and sky high house prices are now an even bigger issue in deciding who will run the country than at the last general election.The poll also reveals that Labour has now leapfrogged the Tories to take a 2 point lead in the marginals among all voters, by 42% v 40%.That reverses the result at last year’s general election where the Tories narrowly came out on top across the 60 tightest races, by 46% v 44% - meaning the party has shed six per of its support in 16 months.All voters in the marginals say they are also now more pessimistic about the state of housing than any other issue.Two thirds of them - 67% - think the cost and availability of housing has got worse over the past five years.In comparison the number worried about rising crime is 66%, those troubled by falling healthcare standards , rising immigration levels , and the poorer quality of schools .Private renters also back an increase in the number of council houses being built over policies to help with homeownership, the poll also found.A total of 39% of them in the marginal said the government should prioritise building more social housing, compared to only 31% who preferred controversial schemes such as Help to Buy.Number Cruncher Politics’s boss Matt Singh said: “Housing was key to last year’s general election result, with renters – and particularly private renters – fuelling the increase in turnout and swing to Labour that cost the Conservatives their majority.“The poll shows that housing is both important to voters in crucial marginal seats, and something they feel particularly gloomy about.“These findings sound a warning to the Tories ahead of their conference.”In what experts dubbed a ‘rentquake’, there was a huge boost in turnout among enraged private renters at the nationwide poll last year.Three in ten renters who voted Tory in 2015 – 29% - abandoned the party in 2017, with three-quarters of them defecting to Labour.Shelter CEO Polly Neate said the research should “set alarm bells ringing for MPs”.Ms Neate added: “Key voters are very pessimistic about the housing crisis, and private renters in particular look like they pose a threat at the ballot box. But there are options on the table to get out of this mess.“As the numbers show, instead of pumping more cash into failed ideas like Help to Buy, we should be building much more social housing to give hard-pressed families an alternative to the private rented sector.“Not only would this be a massive stride towards ending this crisis, but it’d be wildly popular too – so let’s get on with it.”Between 2001 and 2018 the size of the private rental sector doubled, from 11% of the adult population to 28%.The same period also saw a marked decline in the number who own their own home, falling from 73% of the population to 59%.The Tories are consumed by Brexit. But away from that they must wake up and present radical ideas to beat ­Corbyn’s, especially on housing.They have an advantage.Theirs are more likely to be sane.And vanishingly less likely to put hundreds of thousands on the dole.But Theresa May must realise that voters have more pressing problems than Brexit which could cost her power.Next week the Tories must have a new story to tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: motor groups argue fuel duty hike
story: FairFuelUK will meet Treasury Secretary Robert Jenrick on October 9 – amid fears the Chancellor is about to rubber stamp the first increase in the tax for EIGHT YEARS.It comes as sources claim hauliers are preparing to “drive on Parliament” in protest at sky-high petrol prices.Separately, new figures from FairFuel show that struggling Brits are spending up to 25 per cent of their hard-earned cash on filling up their car.Nearly 4 per cent of Brits on £25,000 spend 25 per cent or more on petrol, while nearly a third spend between 15-25 per cent.Other findings from the poll of 71,000 motorists show that 67 per cent of people have “categorically no choice” but to use their car every day.Speaking last night, FairFuel UK co-founder Howard Cox said: “It’s time the Treasury listened to the ‘just about managing’ and got in touch with reality.“Don’t hit those in the pocket who will decide the next Government.It would be political suicide.”Fuel duty has been frozen ever since the Sun’s ‘Keep it Down’ campaign launched in Spring 2011.Chancellor Philip Hammond on Wednesday announced this year’s Budget willtake place on October 29. The early date means it can take place before any potential row with Eurosceptics over the Brexit deal with Brussels.Speaking last month, the Chancellorover the rest of the decade could generate an extra £38 billion for the Treasury.Fuel duty in the UK is among the highest in Europe, at nearly 60p of the pump price.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gay man duped straight tinder
story: Bearded Duerte Xavier, 33, allegedly lured them with female images then arranged blindfolded romps by phone.He performed a sex act on one before intercourse in a park, it was said.The man told how Xavier’s phone voice “sounded feminine and Asian”.He said of their meeting: “I put my scarf around my head and waited.Then it went to taking my trousers down.“I made attempts to touch her, which were thwarted.”The man said the ten-minute act “seemed quite pleasant” before 20 minutes of full sex.He was told to stay blindfolded until Xavier left, Kingston crown court, South West London, heard.Xavier met another man at a local flat after luring him on app Lovoo and WhatsApp, it was said.One Xavier message allegedly demanded: “Be my obedient toy.”As the man headed to the address, Xavier allegedly sent a picture of a blindfolded guy receiving a sex act — an instruction to his victim.The man was buzzed into the flat and told to don a mask before Xavier appeared.The man said: “I wanted to see.I pulled it down and saw this man with a beard.I felt p***** off and slapped him.”The man left but Xavier pestered him to meet again, it was said.The man called police.Xavier, of Bournemouth, denies six charges of causing a person to engage in sex without consent.The trial continues.GOT a story? title: jeremy corbyn leave betray class
story: If selling out Leave voters doesn’t bother you then yes, Michel Barnier and Martin Selmayr — the German bully running the show — will delightedly hear how you intend to achieve it.Which explains why they were so keen to give him an audience yesterday.Betrayal is very much in Corbyn’s plans, as he made clear at his conference.Not only because his party is now firmly behind a second referendum with “Remain” as one of the options.But because he is also determined to stay in the EU’s Customs Union — and thus not leave at all.So, in the unthinkable event of a Labour Government seeing Brexit through, it would do so not via tough negotiations.It would be done by immediate capitulation to Brussels’ demands that the world’s fth biggest economy remain forever under their control.We would be barred in perpetuity from signing trade deals with the faster-growing giant economies of the wider world — and the central economic case for Brexit would be destroyed.So while Corbyn now suddenly claims to care for the forgotten working-class communities who backed Leave, they must never forget this: Labour is now controlled by its middle-class London Remainer membership, all desperate to overturn or negate Brexit.WE’LL be blunt, Becks.It is repugnant to see a celebrity smugly dodge justice solely thanks to being rich enough for a fancy lawyer skilled at exploiting loopholes.Especially when that star freely admits doing 59mph in a 40 zone.Millions of ordinary people grimly suck up fines they can ill afford for far lesser speeding offences.Even  their prosecution letter arrives a day late.Beckham may be within the letter of the law, but not its spirit.That’s a bad look for a man desperate for public adulation and establishment approval.Knighthood? It’s crashed and burned.WE hope the poll revealing voters in ­marginal seats deserting the Tories over sky-high rents is enough to stir the ­Government from its paralysis.The Tories are consumed by Brexit.But away from that they must wake up and present radical ideas to beat ­Corbyn’s, especially on housing.They have an advantage.Theirs are more likely to be sane.And vanishingly less likely to put hundreds of thousands on the dole.But Theresa May must realise that voters have more pressing problems than Brexit which could cost her power.Next week the Tories must have a new story to tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: david beckham nick freeman mr loophole speeding
story: The footie star admitted driving at nearly 60mph in a 40mph zone - but avoided punishment because prosecutors sent him notice of the offence a day late.His lawyer Nick Freeman - dubbed Mr Loophole for his track record of getting celebs out of trouble - said that from a moral standpoint Becks should have been found guilty.And he called on the Government to change the law which lets speeding drivers escape justice because of minor errors by the prosecution.Mr Freeman told the BBCs Today programme: It was made quite clear from the very start that Mr Beckham didnt dispute that he was speeding.Anyone who accepts that they were the driver and they were speeding, you would think in the normal course from a moral standpoint they should be convicted.But  the law of the land, the law laid down by our Government says no actually...The lawyer insisted the case would help the public by making people more aware of the laws they can use to dodge speeding fines.But he added that MPs should vote to close the loophole  they want to bring more rogue drivers to justice.Mr Freeman said: What Parliament needs to do is it needs to change the law.And he also took a dig at prosecutors - suggesting they were targeting Mr Beckham because of his fame and saying an ordinary Joe or ordinary Jane would never have been taken to court.The former England captain was caught doing 59mph in a 40mph at the wheel of a £200,000 Bentley in January this year.But the notice that hed be prosecuted didnt arrive until 15 days after the offence took place - one day after the two-week deadline.Mr Freeman convinced a judge to throw out the case because of the blunder, leaving Mr Beckham very relieved.Road safety campaigners blasted the verdict and said the football legend should have set a better example.

title: cottingley fairies hoax auction
story: But there was a brief period when millions of Brits genuinely did believe in fairies... and they had the photos to prove it.These shots, known as the Cottingley Fairies photos, were taken by two young girls who claimed that they had seen real-le fairies floating around their garden.And now, over a century since the famous photos were taken, they are going to be put up for auction, continuing the strange and twisting tale of the Cottingley Fairies.When the shots were first printed in newspapers in 1920, some dismissed them as a silly prank while other esteemed members of society - including Sherlock Holmes author Sir Arthur Conan Doyle - insisted they were the real deal.For a while, millions were convinced that the shots proved the existence of the mythical beings, and the bizarre chain of events which followed ided society right down the middle.Like many young girls, 16-year-old Elsie Wright and her nine-year-old cousin, Frances Grfiths, believed in fairies.But when they came back from the bottom of their garden with what looked like hard evidence of the creatures existence, everyone else started to believe too.The girls, from the village of Cottingley in Yorkshire, claimed they had taken two photos of the fairies parading around the lawn, with one shot, taken in 1917, even appearing to show Elsie interacting with a winged gnome.Another shows four of the creatures dancing past Frances face, with one appearing to play a trumpet.Elises dad, a keen photographer, believed the photos were clever fakes. But in 1920, Elsies mum, Polly Wright, took the pictures to a mythical research group called the Theosophical Society to be investigated.Leading society member Edward Gardner was instantly taken with the photos. He blew them up into prints and started selling them at his talks.Then, in 1920, keen spiritualist and Holmes author Arthur Conan Doyle came across the photos while he was researching a magazine article about the creatures.He believed they were real and when he published them, he created a national controversy which left some of the most esteemed scientists and thinkers of the time earnestly arguing whether fairies really do exist.Fairy buff Edward Gardner was also convinced. He went to visit the Wright family and set the girls up with a camera so they could capture more evidence.In the summer of 1920, they took three more images of themselves with the fairies, fuelling more interest in the bizarre debate.Doyle also contacted photo company Kodak, asking expert technicians to examine the prints for signs that they had been tampered with.The response was that the photos showed no signs of being faked, although Kodak refused to provide a certicate of authenticity. Doyle maintained that they were real.Newspapers soon picked up on his claims, with some writers agreeing that the photos seemed legitimate, while others poured scorn on the supernatural shots.Some sceptics noted that the fairies looked too traditional to be real, as  they had been plucked out of a nursery rhyme, while other criticisms included the claim that the fairies hairstyles were suspiciously fashionable.Knowing children, and knowing that Sir Arthur Conan Doyle has legs, I decide that they have pulled one of them, one critic wrote.With nobody able to agree, the story eventually died down, only to be reignited decades later with a spectacular twist.In 1966, a reporter tracked down Elsie, who admitted that the fairies might have been figments of my imagination.Frances was also tracked down and quizzed about the photos. A rational person doesnt see fairies, she admitted, but she claimed the photos were genuine nonetheless.However, the cousins eventually confessed that the pictures were a hoax, and that they had made the fairies themselves, before throwing their props into a river to hide the truth.Elise and Frances, by that time old women, conceded in 1983 that they had drawn the mythical beings onto cardboard, cut them out and then arranged them in the garden with hatpins to make them stand up.Bizarrely though, Frances then claimed that one of the five photos - showing a cluster of fairies wading around long grass - was never faked, even though the others were.She also claimed at one point that she really had seen the fairies in real-le, but then staged the photos so she had evidence.Later, in 1985, Elsie revealed why she had gone along with the prank for so long, saying she had been embarrassed about fooling Conan Doyle and didnt want to show him up.Two village kids and a brilliant man like Conan Doyle – well, we could only keep quiet, she said.Frances added: I never even thought of it as being a fraud – it was just Elsie and I having a bit of fun and I cant understand to this day why they were taken in.A year later, Frances died, and Elsie followed in 1988. However, their hoax remains commonly thought of as one of the greatest ruses of the 20th century, and the legacy of their photos lives on today.Expected to sell for at least £2,000, the first two Cottingley Fairy photos are being auctioned off in Gloucester on October 4, when a new owner can get their hands on a piece of history - and a little bit of real-le magic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum poo vagina routine operation
story: Yasna Cortes Caceres, 31, says that she decided to have her Fallopian tubes tied last October because she didnt want to have more kids - at least for the time being.But she claims that the operation, which took place at Quilque Hospital, in central Chile, went wrong and caused her to defecate through her vagina as cuts in her large intestine caused a fistula - an abnormal connection between two hollow spaces in the body.Shes now due for a third operation to correct the horric problem, having had a colostomy bag fitted during a second operation.Ms Caceres says that she uses three to four colostomy bags a day, with each one costing her the equivalent of £46 each.She also claims that her Fallopian tubes were removed without her consent - making the prospect of her ever being able to have kids again pretty unlikely.The 31-year-old has apparently had to leave her job and is now receiving psychological help from the health authorities to help her deal with whats happened.After her case made headlines in Chile, the head of Quilque Hospital, Alejandro Alarcon Landerretche, reportedly called Ms Caceres to promise her that shed be seen to in the following weeks.That prevents eggs from reaching the uterus. That means that your eggs cant meet sperm and therefore fertilisation cant happen. Your eggs will simply be absorbed into your body after being released from the oies.Most women go home the same day but as with any surgery, theres a small risk of complications.These include:And of course, theres a small risk that the operation wont work - blocked tubes can rejoin immediately or years after the surgery.But one things for sure - a successful surgery is very dficult to reverse, so you have to be sure that its right for you.Source:  NHSOne solution put forward was to have the mum moved to another hospital which is better equipped with more facilities and resources, and where she could be seen by a specialist who might be able to correct the errors made in the first operation.A spokesperson for the hospital told reporters that all clinical procedures were followed during Ms Caceres initial operation and that after her second surgery to insert the colostomy bag she was monitored correctly.Despite this, they do also claim that something is going to be done about Caceres current condition.As yet, its unclear whether she intends to sue the hospital for medical negligence.

title: driver parking ticket driveway croydon
story: Celia Hossenbux, 66, from South Croydon, claims the vehicle was only blocking part of the pavement outside her home for a couple of minutes but was still given a fine.She says she was forced to stop partially on the pavement as her home was having the guttering done and her husband had parked further back than normal.Mrs Hossenbux says she ran into the house to get him to move his car but in that time she had been given a ticket.She told the Croydon Advertiser: I came in as far as I could, I blocked a small area of the pavement but before I came in I checked behind to make sure I was not blocking too much of it.My son is disabled and uses a wheelchair so I am always aware that there needs to be room.By the time I came out there was a ticket, it was done it such a swt time which makes it more unbelievable - I was back out there in a couple of minutes.She added the reason she did not reverse out of the driveway when she knew she couldn’t park properly was because motorists regularly broke the 20mph speed limit and it was “suicidal” to reverse into road.Mrs Hossenbux received the ticket in May and has had two appeals rejected by the council since then.She has refused to pay the £195 fine and said she could be taken to court.She said: I think they really just want to make money out of people like me.There is no other reason why they would reject that [appeal]. I am a pensioner, it is a lot of money for me to have to pay.A Croydon Council spokesman said: We enforce restrictions against parking on pavements to ensure everyone, including those with reduced mobility or other needs, can use the pavement.Anyone who believes a penalty charge notice has been issued incorrectly can make representation to the council and  they are not happy with the decision they can appeal to an independent adjudicator.

title: moth memes trending internet
story: Over the last two months the insects have taken over the internet after a Reddit user shared a creepy, close-up picture of a moth outside their window.People on the internet went crazy for the picture and started making original memes that have everyone cracking up.The theme consistent in all the memes is the moths unconditional love for lamps.As we all know the insects are attracted to light, especially when its a lamp close to a human in indoors so they can inflict the most distress.There are some takes on well-worn classics, such as the jealous girlfriend meme and the Drake Hotline Bling Meme.Meanwhile others have opted for more original memes which have not disappointed.They all include lamps as the main focus and each meme uses the original photo shared on Reddit.The trend shows no signs of slowing down as more and more people join the moth meme bandwagon.The hashtag #mothmemes has over 5,600 posts on Instagram and theres even an account dedicated to the phenomenon called @moth_memes.Moths are attracted to light because they use the moon as a navigation system as theyre nocturnal insects.But unfortunately, moths arent able to distinguish between the moon and other sources of light.The term for a moths attraction to light is phototaxis, as it uses light  to move .Unfortunately, the invention of the light bulb has prevented moths from properly navigating.They circle around the light, trying to get the correct alignment with the light source, as they would with the moon, but because the light is so close, it confuses the moth.They get closer and closer to the light until they touch it, which in some cases kills the moth.The part of the moths brain that causes it to travel towards the light is called the Icarus cell.This is a reference to the classical story Icarus and Daedalus, in which Icarus is killed for flying too close to the sun.Its a tragic tale of the moth being killed by the thing it loves the most.

title: mh370 flight mobile phone conspiracy theory
story: The Malaysian Airlines jet vanished on March 8, 2014, en route to Beijing from Kuala Lumper killing 239 people on board - with officials believing it crashed into the sea.One theory claims that because many relatives were able to hear a ringing tone for up to four days after the crash the doomed jet could not have smashed into the Indian Ocean.However, wireless analysts claim that phone firms sometimes use a phantom ringing sound when the device is not active, the Daily Star reports.The companies do this to keep callers on the line while the network tries to connect the call.As a result, a ringing sound does not always mean the phone which is being called is still active.Nineteen families have all claimed the devices of their loved ones rang for up to four days after the jet went missing.One family member appeared on television in China and rang his dead brother’s phone to prove it was still ringing.Indeed, telecommunications expert Paul Franks disagrees with the phantom ring tone theory insisting the aircraft could not have been submerged in water.On Reddit, Franks wrote: “If the plane had crashed into the Indian Ocean, there is no way the phones would still ring.“It’s not possible. As soon as a phone is submerged in water, especially sea water, it dies.“Even  it were to survive, it would not get signal from the bottom of the ocean. All this shows the plane did not crash into the sea.”A 449-page final report released in July by the Malaysian government only deepened the mystery - revealing that the plane’s sudden change in direction was a deliberate manoeuvre by somebody in the cockpit.However what caused the Boeing 777 to ert 37 minutes remains a puzzle with most of the pieces missing.Some feared Russian president Vladimir Putin was involved in the hijacking of MH370.US Science writer Jeff Wise claimed Putin spoofed the planes navigation data so it could fly unnoticed into Baikonur Cosmodrome so he could hurt the West.French ex-airline director Marc Dugain accused the US military of shooting down the plane because they feared it had been hijacked.Malaysia police chief Tan Sri Khalid Abu Bakar suggested the disappearance could have been the result of a suicide.He claimed someone on board could have taken out a large le insurance package before getting on the plane, so they could treat their family or pay back the money they owed.Historian and writer Norman Davies suggested MH370 could have been remotely hacked and flown to a secret location as a result of sensitive material being carried aboard the jet.Malaysia Airlines found a 15-inch crack in the fuselage of one of its planes, days before MH370 disappeared.The Federal Aviation Administration insists it issued a final warning two days before the disappearance.But the Daily Mirror claimed the missing jet did not have the same antenna as the rest of the Boeing 777s so it did not receive the warning.Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull unexpectedly said it was “very likely that the captain planned this shocking event”.He claimed the pilot wanted to create the worlds greatest mystery.Another theory claimed that he hijacked his own plane in protest of the jailing of then-Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, and as a way to destabilise the corrupt government of Najib Razak.In the wake of the incident, South Korea noted that North Korea nearly took out a Chinese plane which had 220 passengers on board, on March 5, 2014.Some fear Pyongyang shot the plane down, but others believe it was hijacked and erted into the communist nation.In September 2018, British video producer Ian Wilson claimed to have found the missing aircraft using Google Maps.Despite millions being spent on the search to located the wreckage, the Brit sleuth believes he has found the jet in a mountainous area of the Cambodian jungle.In response, the Chinese government used observation company Space View to focus in on the high-altitude area on the outskirts of Phnom Penh.However, the firm claim there was no sign of any plane, least of all the Malaysian Airlines aircraft which has been missing since March 2014.

title: sizzling summer and cheap mouse traps have sparked a plague of maggots in the uk
story: A plague of MAGGOTS is sweeping the nation after the warm weather caused a surge of infestations in homes up and down the country.The scorching temperatures have provided flies with the perfect nesting conditions, meaning their offspring - maggots - have been hatching and thriving in record numbers.But thats not the only problem.Now temperatures are dropping, rats and mice are are retreating inside, and homeowners are killing them with shop bought poisons.The rodents are then dying in the walls and vents of houses - and flies are feeding on them and nesting in their corpses. Now, more and more Brits are finding nests of maggots in their homes.The soft white wriggly worm-like larvae can hatch in as little as 24 hours in the heat - and live for five days before turning into flies.Peter Higgs, who runs PGH Pest Control and Prevention, tells Sun Online he has received an unprecedented number of call outs to deal with maggots over the past week.“We’ve had at least a hundred calls over the summer. That’s more than double what we’d normally receive, he says.It’s not just maggots in bins, they’re dropping from the ceiling in homes and shops.”And Peter says we are ALL responsible for the maggot population explosion.“Britain’s hot summer has meant there was a healthy fly count. We’ve all been outside in the garden or parks for picnics, he tells Sun Online.“When food gets left in the heat it rots quicker as bacteria forms much faster in warm temperatures. It’s a feasting ground for flies.“It means that maggots are hatching in gardens, bins and also on dead animals around suburban homes and gardens.”According to Peter, home and business owners are only now discovering they are living with maggots thanks to the recent drop in temperatures.“Rats and mice aren’t stupid. If a building isn’t rodent proof they know how to get in out the cold.The problem is, when well-meaning homeowners put down DIY poisoning theyll die in the walls – but flies lay their eggs on those rotting corpses.“This week we’ve been called out to an opticians with maggots falling from the ceiling in the client waiting area. That was as the result of a dead animal in the vents.“A restaurant also had to temporarily shut up shop because maggots were dropping down into their customers food. It is distressing for everyone involved.”Maggots can be killed with boiling water – but pest control experts advise to always look for the reason behind why the maggots hatched in the first place.Peter’s advice is simple: “As disgusting as they are there is always an even more sinister reason you’ve got them. Identy that and you’re sorted.“It could be a dead pigeon in the roof or a poisoned rotting mouse under the floorboards. Flies love bacteria-spewing corpses and will lay dozens of eggs on them.“If they are in your bins – you need to make sure clean them out regularly, with a disinfectant. They need a good seal and ensure that rubbish is properly bagged up.“Finally make sure your building is pest proof.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: inside filthy subway hull zero hygiene rating
story: A report on the branch in St Stephen’s Shopping Centre in Hull highlighted ious hygiene problems with the fast-food outlet, including evidence of flies in the preparation area.Alarming pictures taken of the Subway branch show the extent of the filth with what looks like food splattered on the work surfaces that hasnt been cleaned up.In one image discarded food is scattered all over the floor while in another what looks like dirt is stuck to the wall.A sign was also put up over a sink telling staff not to use it.The report, obtained by the Hull Daily Mail, said: “Evidence of flies were found in the sandwich preparation area and in the rear storage/pot wash area.These pests carry food poisoning bacteria and can contaminate food surfaces that they land on.”It also criticised the cleanliness of the premises, saying its standard was “generally poor”.An inspector said: “A thorough deep clean and disinfection is required. All areas must be maintained in a clean condition.”Inspectors swooped on the premises after receiving a complaint about a lack of hot water on the premises.The unnamed inspector said: “There was no supply of hot water to the sinks and wash hand basins at the premises due to a fault with the boiler.“A supply of constant running hot and cold water must be provided in order to allow for effective cleaning of the premises and hand washing to be carried out.”Inspectors also highlighted the branch’s poor stock rotation after a container of porridge oats was found to have an expired best before date.After it was inspected the branch was given a zero hygiene rating.The branch was then voluntarily down.According to the paper, the chain has vowed to seek a re-inspection once all the issues in the report have been rectied.A spokeswoman for Subway told The Sun: We have clear expectations and procedures in place to ensure that stores serve products that meet our food safety standards.Immediate action was taken regarding the issues highlighted and were rectied two months ago.The Environmental Health Officer has confirmed that all works have been carried out to their satisfaction and will re-visit the store once three months have passed, and we look forward to their next inspection.All staff have received hygiene and food safety re-training in Food Safety Levels 1 and 2.The Sun has contacted Hull Council for comment.

title: m27 closure diversion 58 mile route
story: The M27 will shut between junction 3 and junction 5 from 10pm tonight until 5am on Monday morning.It will close as part of a £19million renovation project to replace the two Romsey Road bridges over the motorway.Cars and other small vehicles will be able to take shorter routes.But truckers face a mammoth 58-mile ersion which has been set up by Highways England bosses.They will have to go from the closure in Southampton, up to Salisbury and then back to Southapmton via the A34.The normal journey would take less than ten minutes but the new route across two counties will take two hours.Hampshire Fire and Rescue Service described it as the biggest traffic ersion ever in the country. Duncan Buchanan, policy director for the Road Haulage Association [RHA], slammed the plans.He said: I am stunned by the suggested alternative route for HGVs, it is truly an enormous distance.“It is a monster ersion, taking lorries a zillion miles out of their way.We think of Highways England as having one job to do and that is to run the road network correctly for key users.Its a debacle and they are not focused on this and key road users.”The RHA said a single trip along the ersion route would cost a haulier an extra £35 in fuel alone.Malcolm Gibson, managing director of Hampshire-based international freight company Steve Porter Transport, said: It will certainly affect some of our customers who are travelling to us.“The section between junctions three and five is an integral part of the M27 for hauliers.Highways England said the closure was picked at the quietest of times.A spokesman for Highways England said: Completing these key phases of work at the weekend means that restrictions can be kept to a minimum at other, busier, times.“We understand that these closures will inevitably cause considerable disruption in the area and we advise that road users plan journeys in advance, especially those heading for the ports.“We also urge drivers – especially those of HGVs or similar heavy and high-sided vehicles – to follow the signed ersion routes as these have been chosen as they are the most suitable routes and can cope with heavy flows of traffic.”Further weekend closures are scheduled next year between April 26-29 and October 18-21.The project, which began in the spring, is expected to finish in January 2020.

title: angela merkel wants to stop britain thriving after brexit david davis blasts
story: The former Brexit Secretary said only French president Emmanuel Macron is taking a harder line against the UK than the German Chancellor, accusing them of being ‘emphatic about us not being seen to succeed’.Speaking to the Evening Standard on the eve of Tory conference, Mr Davis predicted the negotiations will “go the distance”, with any trade deal being clinched only at the last minute.The ex-Cabinet minister also branded the Salzburg summit, where the Prime Minister’s Chequers pan was mauled by EU leaders, a “collective cock-up ... on both sides”.But he reserved his anger at the impasse in the talks on getting an agreement hammered out for Mr Macron.Mr Davis pointed the finger firmly at Paris for “playing hardball”, saying there are three “strong elements” driving its policy.He said one was the “daft argument” that it will only encourage others  the UK gets a good deal.The second: “Is a very, very narrow French one of trying, as it were, to raid our economy to get businesses to go to France.”And the third is the “hysterically wrong” French view of “what they think of us as deregulatory ‘Wild West’ Anglo-Saxon approach to economics”.The 69-year-old, who stood down in July over Mrs May’s draft proposals, also hit out at Ms Merkel.He said: “I don’t think Merkel was ever really going to be our champion, ever, ever … neither Macron, nor Merkel.”Elsewhere in the interview he said Mrs May has to show the Tory conference in Birmingham she is “tough enough to stand up” to Brussels.But he warned of more Brexit turmoil ahead, stressing it is “tough now but it will get tougher” as the countdown to the end of Article 50 approaches.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: david beckham lawyer mr loophole
story: Once again he lives up to it after helping David Beckham escape prosecution yesterday – even though he accepted the ex-England captain was speeding.His tactic? He proved that Becks’ notice of prosecution had arrived a day later than it should have. Mr Loophole – real name Nick Freeman – is the lawyer of choice for celebrities who want to get off a driving charge .Sir Alex Ferguson avoided being punished for driving on the hard shoulder of the motorway after Freeman argued in court that the former Manchester United manager was having a “squeaky bum time”, desperately driving to use the Old Trafford toilet while suffering an upset stomach.No stranger to controversy, the lawyer caused a furore this year after suggesting that women who didnt want to be upskirted should “should dress more conservatively”.“The more provocative the attire,” he argued, “the greater risk of someone wanting to have a sneaky view.”Freeman clearly loves his job. He’s written before that loop-hole hunting has left him “almost shaking with excitement ”.If youre a Peeping Tom, or any other kind of law-breaker, in need of help, Freeman could probably mount an effective defence –  you can afford his astronomical fees.But helpfully, Freeman wrote a book, called, of course, The Art of The Loophole.It details his sneaky legal knowledge that has got the likes of Ronnie OSullivan, Sir Alex Ferguson, Freddy Flintoff and Charlotte Crosby off the hook.So  you cant afford thousands, here are some tips from his book that will help you beat the rap.As a rookie prosecutor, he lost a drunk-driving case because hed hadnt submitted a printout of the breathalyser record, only getting a police officer to say the reading in court. If you want to escape law, you should check  the prosecution has followed the law and submitted its evidence correctly. Any little cock-up by them could be your ticket to freedom.Having saved Fergie his licence by arguing for the poor state of the Scotsmans bowels , he thinks medical reasons can be a strong defence.If you couldnt blow into a breathalyser because you had a cold, “then it could be recorded on the station’s CCTV. And there may be ious officers who might remember whether or not you were sneezing or coughing.” But “you can’t simply make it up,” he counsels. “Otherwise you waste my time and your money”.“You might think that in our over-scrutinised, flash-happy age of the speed camera, proving the identity of the driver in a motoring case is fairly easy,” Freeman says. “Not so.” Having got footballer Ashley Ward off a speeding rap by arguing the prosecution couldnt prove the identity of the driver. “If a policeman doesn’t ask for some kind of concrete ID, such as a driving licence with a photo, he leaves himself wide open to being unable to confirm identity,” advises Mr Loophole, having seen the Crown lose many cases because lazy coppers didnt ask for official identication.He recalls another case: “Court papers referred to my client as exposing his penis. He claimed that it was his testes. Could the Crown be sure beyond reasonable doubt that they could ID his anatomy?”Don’t blab your story, even to your solicitor. “It’s not my job to prove he wasn’t disqualied,” he writes of a case, “it’s the Crown’s to prove he was”. So dont admit to any possible wrongdoings to a lawyer – and possibly compromising them – and just let them see  the Crown can make a case against, and there may be “a whole assortment of defects in the paperwork alone that might stop them from doing that.”When Lee Bowyer was convicted for speeding, allegedly peaking at 132mph in his Porsche, Freeman noticed slight dferences in the officers four reports. This weakened the case enough to help him to get the Crown to accept a plea of speeding at 99mph, giving Bowyer a ban of only six weeks and no penalty points. Similarly, Dwight Yorke was pulled over for allegedly driving at 102mph, but the officer made seven subsequent changes to his first report – making for a shaky case that resulted in only a fourteen-day ban.Freeman advises that we always check the small print: “wherever you get paperwork, human error isn’t lagging far behind.” The most common errors being “names are misspelt, or wrong addresses or dates are recorded, notices or,” as happened with Beckham this week, “summonses arrive after the allotted time for their dispatch has expired.” Each and any error is a possible escape route from conviction. “The trick then is to be able to spot such errors. There’s no real skill here – just a laser-like focus.”Freeman once got a client off the hook after hed refused to take a breathalyser test following crash that devastated a family. The police failed to charge him for his refusal, wanting to get him to take a blood test – the results of which were inadmissible because the rules hadnt been obeyed. “If the police had followed the correct protocol my client would have been convicted,” admits Freeman. “It was because of this error – this loophole – that he walked free.”A brilliantly successful lawyer, Freeman focuses on making sure the Crown has done its job properly.If it hasnt then whether you did or didnt commit a crime doesnt matter. No case is too big to fail  they havent made it properly, and can be beaten just by looking for the largely minor mistakes.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: slum landlord brent 20 tenants house
story: Landlord Pathanchaly Anandamohanadas, 69, admitted he owned the three-bed semi-detached property crammed with Romanian builders.Outside his £500,000 home in Letchworth, Herts, he refused to say when he last inspected the property or  he knew over a dozen men were living inside.The local authority raided the house at 5am on Thursday and discovered over 20 men living in “appalling and unsafe” conditions.Anandamohanadas laughed at photos from the raid but said “no comment” when asked  he was sorry about the conditions his tenants lived in.He added: “I have rights, I ask that you respect my freedom and my civilisation.”At the property in Brent, north west London, a Romanian tenant confirmed he had lived inside the house for a month.The disgusting conditions, for which the men were paying between £30 and £50 to live in, also had faulty smoke alarms, poor ventilation and fire hazards.The tenant said: “I was there when the police raided at 5am, I have lived there for a month and pay around £50.“My friend told me about the house, I don’t see what the problem is with living there. It’s a bit cramped, a bit tight, but it’s fine.”Today Anandamohanadas told The Sun he had no idea his property had been raided.He said: “This is the first I’ve heard of this. I was there at 10am yesterday.”In stark contrast to the property he rents to tenants making £1,000 a week, his immaculate home lies in a quiet cul-de-sac in Letchworth, Hertfordshire.A white Toyota Rav 4 in the driveway and the house has large extension with a private garden.Outside the rented property occupied by Romanian builders a tenant said: “I sublet from another tenant. I’ve been in the UK since 2010 so I’m kind of a British citizen.”Furious neighbours Karson Mepani, 64 and his we Manbai, 62, have complained to the council about the slum housing and claim food and cigarette butts are thrown into their garden.They also claim their Romanian neighbours play loud music from 10pm at night and are regularly heard fighting and shouting between each other in the house.Karson Mepani said: “It has been let out for the past two or three years.“But the landlord does not know about what the letting agent is doing.“They play loud Romanian music from 10pm until the early hours especially on Saturdays, the noise is dreadful.“We also regularly hear them fighting inside, shouting and screaming at each other.“We are p****d off, I would not mind 50 people living next door  they weren’t so noisy.“Several times we have had food and cigarette ends thrown into our garden.“They are also hanging clothes out to dry on the fence between our houses.“They are disruptive neighbours and we are delighted that someone is finally doing something about it.”A spokeswoman for Brent Council said it was one of the worst illegal HMOs it has uncovered.She said: Aside from seeing rodents or cockroaches it is one of the worst we have seen.The loft was just appalling - really awful conditions.

title: how boris gove sajid and more are using tory conference to launch their leadership campaigns because theyre convinced may is toast
story: Bookies predict the gathering which starts on Sunday will be Theresa Mays last as PM - Ladbrokes is offering odds of 4/6 that a new leader will be in place within a year.So several of the top candidates to replace her are now competing to boost their popularity with activists and their fame among the public.Well-known Tories are planning to speak at multiple fringe meetings, setting out their vision for Britain and their election pitch.Here we profile the top candidates who are clamouring for position over the four-day conference.Boris Johnson is the bookies favourite to take over from Theresa May - with odds of 10/1 that hell be the leader a year from now.At the party conference hes keeping his powder relatively dry, doing just one fringe event.But that meeting - in a hall with a capacity of 1,000 - is set to be one of the standout moments of the conference.Boris will be keen to prove hes still a superstar among the Tory faithful who have the last say on who will succeed Mrs May.Michael Gove, who as Environment Secretary is hailed as one of the most dynamic Cabinet ministers, is listed to speak at least five times.He is attempting to burnish his green credentials by appearing at events hosted by farming and environment groups.Mr Gove hopes that developing a pro-environment image will help him with swing voters around the country.Sajid Javid is seen as the frontrunner for the leadership among ministers who voted Remain in the EU referendum.As well as making a speech from the conferences main stage, hes expected to appear at a number of carefully picked fringe events.He will address one meeting debating the importance of law and order - his current brief as Home Secretary.And crucially, Mr Javid is helping to host a reception for MPs elected since 2015 - who could hold the key to the next leadership election because theyre seen as being less committed to a particular candidate already.Liz Truss, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, is fast developing a reputation as the Cabinets resident Tigger because of her upbeat demeanour and raft of policy ideas.Shes now regarded as a dark horse for the leadership, with her quirky Instagram account gaining her fans from among young activists.Ms Truss is speaking at several fringe events - mostly aimed at promoting free-market ideas and appealing to the youth.Priti Patel was forced to quit the Cabinet last year after meeting Israeli politicians in secret.But she still harbours leadership ambitions and hopes to overtake Boris and Mr Gove among Brexiteers.So she is appearing at a number of high-profile fringes, including a pro-Brexit rally and a think-tank debate on the future of Conservatism.Amber Rudd is another ex-minister who still hasnt given up on the aim of making it to 10 Downing Street one day.As a former Home Secretary, she is an expert on immigration and security policy - two of the most important areas for the Tory grassroots.Ms Rudd is speaking on security in the internet age at one fringe, and attending two talks on migration.Jacob Rees-Mogg was the main attraction at last years conference, with every event he spoke at packed out with adoring activists.This year hes dialled it back a bit - but hes still scheduled to speak at seven dferent fringes.Observers will be keen to see whether he still has the same star power as he did a year ago.

title: faces women sitting behind brett
story: NewsFaces of women sitting behind Brett Kavanaugh sum up the disgust and ision in AmericaIt's the sexual assault claims hearing that has ided America. And this extraordinary photo sums it up - though not in the way you might thinkShare&nbspByDan BloomOnline Political Editor11:12, 28 SEP 2018NewsTo the left and right of the Donald Trump's Supreme Court nominee sit five women, all with looks of disgust and horror "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt's the sexual assault claims hearing that has ided and enraged America. And nothing could sum that up more than this extraordinary photo of Brett Kavanaugh on 'trial' in a court of public opinion - the US Senate. To the left and right of the Donald Trump's Supreme Court nominee sit five women, all with looks of disgust and horror rippling across their faces. But it is not what it first appears. Far from being accusers, disgusted with the 53-year-old's alleged actions, they are his family and his allies. Their disgust could therefore be assumed to be about the fact the allegations have surfaced in the first place.  To his right sit his mother Martha Kavanaugh, family friend Laura Cox Kaplan and his we Ashley Kavanaugh. To his left are longtime friend Suzanne Matan and former clerk Zina Bash.  The photo captures an extraordinary saga that has transfixed the US and ided supporters and critics of Donald Trump even further than before.  University professor Christine Blasey Ford fought tears yesterday as she said Kavanaugh assaulted her at a High School party, declaring: I believed he was going to rape me. Saying she was 15 and he 17, she told the Senate Judiciary Committee: Brett groped me and tried to take off my clothes. He had a hard time because he was very inebriated and because I was wearing a one-piece bathing suit under my clothing.  She said she tried to yell for help but Kavanaugh put his hand over her mouth. He and a friend of his were drunkenly laughing during the attack, she added. Dr Ford said she could not remember the location or exact date of the incident 36 years ago, but said she was 100% sure it was Kavanaugh who assaulted her. She told the senators she was terried to testy but felt it was her civic duty to come forward. And two other women, Deborah Ramirez and Julie Swetnick, have accused conservative Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct in the 1980s. But in an angry, extraordinary statement yesterday, Kavanaugh blasted Democratic senators and accused opponents of a calculated and orchestrated political hit.  Calling himself a victim of grotesque and obvious character assassination, Kavanaugh said he unequivocally and categorically denied Ford's allegation. I swear today, under oath, before the Senate and the nation, before my family and God, I am innocent of this charge, he said. He added: I will not be intimidated into withdrawing from this process.  Dr Ford told the hearing she feared he would rape and accidentally kill her.  I am an independent person and I am no one's pawn, she said.

title: head teachers march against school
story: NewsHead teachers march against school cuts in suits and ties in 1,000-strong protest at Downing StreetWith banners saying ‘fund state education properly’ and ‘Head teachers say there is nothing left to cut’ they brought traffic to a temporary standstill in Parliament SquareShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByHelena KellyMark Ellis12:27, 28 SEP 2018Updated15:48, 28 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/headteachers-march-london-more-funding-13325044,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA thousand head teachers today took their protest over school cuts to Downing Street. With banners saying ‘fund state education properly’ and ‘Head teachers say there is nothing left to cut’ they brought traffic to a temporary standstill in Parliament Square. Unlike many protests in the square the leaders were dressed for business - in suits and ties. Mr Rob Kelsall of the campaign group Worth Less?, which organised the march, said: “We are seeing schools that are seeing their funds depleted, dipping into their reserves, and having to send out begging letters to parents. This is not through choice, this is because there is no alternative.” Scroll down for what teachers themselves say about the crisis.  In July, the Institute for Fiscal Studies said total school spending per pupil fell around 8% in real terms in England between 2009/10 and 2017/18. In response, the Government said it was spending record amounts on schools. Paul Whiteman, general secretary of 29,000-strong school leaders’ union NAHT, said schools were at “breaking point” and almost three-quarters of heads say they will be unable to balance their budgets for next year. The protest is being organised by grassroot groups and not unions, but Mr Whiteman said: Head teachers are not normally the marching kind. So, when they do, it must be serious. “They’re sick of being told that there’s more money in education than ever before, when what they see with their own eyes every day proves that it’s just not enough. “More and more now, children succeed despite the system, not because of it. And that can’t be right.”  Organisers estimate more than 1,500 had turned out, and burst into applause as they lined up on Whitehall when they were told the letter had been delivered in Downing Street. Police estimate 2,000 people took part. A Department for Education spokeswoman said: There is more money going into schools than ever before, rising to a record &pound43.5 billion by 2020 – 50% more in real terms per pupil than in 2000. The OECD has recently confirmed that the UK is the third highest spender on education in the world, spending more per pupil than countries including Germany, Australia and Japan. “Every school attracts more funding per pupil through the National Funding Formula, high needs funding has risen to over &pound6 billion this year and the 3.5% pay rise we announced for classroom teachers on the main pay range is backed by &pound508 million government funding. What head teachers told us about the schools crisis  Elaine Ball, 52, from Orleans Park School in Twickenham said:  “Teachers are being asked to do so much more with so much less. “We now have to put money into frontline care, my school has to fund a mental health worker and an educational psychologist to come in once a week - that’s on top of everything else “Things are so bad we’ve had to ask parents for money to fund a new food and nutrition classroom, a second-hand minibus and an updated IT suite.” Susan Pietrzak, 44, from Manor Field Infant School in Basingstoke said: “The only way we’re going to balance the books is by losing really great teachers and teaching assistants. “We’re not a radical bunch. We’re not asking for more than any of the other services. We just want fair funding.”  Katherine Warren, 49, from Kea Schools in Trurow, Cornwall, said:  “The amount it takes to run a school is more and more. We’re spending more money on resources such as special needs, professional agencies, educational psychologists - services we didn’t previously pay for. “I don’t know any school that at the very least hasn’t had to reduce hours of staff. It makes it so hard to meet the needs of the children “There’s such pressure to have a lovely, broad balanced curriculum and that’s what we hope to do. We don’t want the children to go out just being able to do English and Maths, we want them to leave as rounded human beings.” Cathy Rowland, 54, from Dobcroft Infant School in Sheffield, said:  “Headteachers are a mild mannered bunch.  “We understand austerity and we’ve made the easier cuts but now when we look ahead the only cuts we’ve got left will seriously damage the education of children.  “I know of schools in Sheffield that have had to reduce their curriculum choices for children, I know of schools that have increased their class sizes, a lot of us have cut teaching hours.  “Our library is still flooded from rain last week. “When you go into education, you don’t expect to end up worrying about whether you’ve got enough buckets in case it rains.”

title: im not your mate labours

title: tories blues head birmingham mirror
story: NewsopinionWhy the Tories have the blues as they head to Birmingham: Mirror Politics morning briefingThe Conservatives gather for the annual conference ided over Brexit and riddled with anxiety over the party's future directionShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics08:54, 28 SEP 2018NewsopinionTory MPs are turning on Theresa May for her lack of vision "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Conservatives go into their conference this weekend riddled with insecurity.   They were already braced for the gathering to be dominated by rows over Brexit  but Jeremy Corbyn’s assured speech setting out a bold agenda has deepened the sense of anxiety.   Tory MPs are now thrashing around for a policy agenda to counter the popular appeal of Corbynism.   To add to the unease they are led by a Prime Minister ill-equipped to the task of refashioning Conservatism to fit the new age.   Theresa May’s record in the Home Office should have alerted her party to her inability and unwillingness to engineer reform.   Despite being the longest serving Home Secretary of modern times her time in the department was an exercise in survival rather than modernisation.      There were a few welcome policies such as tackling modern slavery but she did almost nothing during her time to bring about transformative change.   The one reform she did oversee, the creation of elected police and crime commissioners, has produced no noticeable dference beyond providing a regular reminder that the public can easily get voter fatigue  asked to trudge to the ballot box too often.   This cautious way of operating has continued in Downing Street where she has failed to follow through her diagnosis of the country’s problems with any meaningful action to address them.   In less turbulent times a Prime Minister may be able to get away with timid measures but Mrs May is tiptoeing through office during a period when, as one of her MPs has put it, capitalism is in the dock.   Conservative MPs and commentators have finally woken up to the fact that Jeremy Corbyn’s radical agenda is increasingly popular among voters who are witnessing daily the failures of privatisation, globalism and austerity.   Challenging Corbynism is all the harder when Brexit and the Prime Minister’s personality have led to stasis in Downing Street.   In this vacuum Tories are now wrestling with whether to try to offer a pale imitation of Corbyn or rush further to the right with an unapologetic free-market agenda.   All of this is made harder when they look increasingly out of touch with a generation of younger voters who not only resent Brexit but blame the Conservatives for a lack of affordable housing, insecure and low-paid work and burdening them with student debts.   As the Tory MP George Freeman writes in the House Magazine unless Conservative Party “reconnects with them, we risk becoming a rump party of nostalgic nationalists.”

title: tories mired open revolt days
story: NewsTories mired in open revolt days before Theresa May addresses make-or-break party conferenceEven serving ministers have clashed over housing, the economy and most of all Brexit - with the civil war set to dominate the get-together in BirminghamShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor14:15, 28 SEP 2018Updated14:17, 28 SEP 2018NewsTheresa May has to persuade EU leaders like Emmanuel Macron... and her own party "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBitter infighting risks tearing apart the Conservatives just hours before thousands of activists descend on the party's annual conference.  Even serving ministers have clashed over housing, the economy and most of all Brexit - with the civil war set to dominate the get-together in Birmingham.   Today Boris Johnson led the charge by launching his most stinging outburst yet against Theresa May’s Brexit plan. The Chequers blueprint is as “a moral and intellectual humiliation for this country” that will “cheat the electorate”, he wrote in the .   Hard Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg echoed Mr Johnson’s call to chuck the so-called 'Chequers' plan, saying it didn’t “have much le in the sunlight”.   Meanwhile ex-leader Michael Howard has said Mrs May is only safe for a few months in a recording leaked to The Sun. Universities Minister Sam Gyimah wrote that the Tories “have lost our way” and now veer between “talking business down” and “ignoring the concerns of voters.” And Chief Secretary to the Treasury Liz Truss said: “We need to be talking about how people’s lives are getting better.”  The annual get-together in Birmingham will be a make-or-break time for the Prime Minister, whose leadership is under strain as she bids to compromise with the EU to get a Brexit deal. She must rally angry Tory Brexiteers around the plan in her speech on Wednesday, just days before trying to persuade pro-EU leaders of its merits in Brussels.  But Jeremy Corbyn's focus on domestic poverty, austerity and jobs - together with a slick new campaign video - have led to Tories voicing their fears about the party's bigger picture.   Ms Truss made her comment at an event in response to the Labour video. She added: That video does capture the heart of where we need to be as a party. Serving minister Mr Gyimah lamented that the hard left have glitzy ambassadors from Stormzy to the Archbishop of Canterbury. Meanwhile on his own side, he said, when we Conservatives veer between talking business down, ignoring voters’ concerns, and telling businesses to shut up – or worse – it is a clear sign we have lost our way. When it comes to our relationship with business, we must unscramble our compass  we are to stand any chance of defeating the hard left.

story: NewsAuthor Judith Kerr - 'No-one would notice a tiger in the street - everyone's on their phones' as she takes aim at parents in new bookBest-selling author Judith Kerr has taken a wry look at mobile phone use among parents in a new bookShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySteve Myall12:30, 28 SEP 2018Updated13:34, 28 SEP 2018NewsJudith Kerr at work at home in Barnes 2013 Eliz Huseyin"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe author of the iconic children's book The Tiger who Came to Tea has turned her ire on parents who use mobile phones when caring for their kids in her new story. Judith Kerr has written Mummy Time which is described as an an ironic story of a mum on her mobile phone in the park whilst her toddler gets up to all kinds of wild adventures. In the book a child is shown patting a growling dog, eating bread left by a man feeding ducks off the floor, falling into a pond and climbing a tree all while her mum chats on her mobile phone obliviously.  Kerr, 95, who has sold millions of books including her famous story of a tiger visiting a mother and daughter for tea, said: If a tiger was running down the street, I would probably be the only person to notice it because everybody else is on their mobile phones. People who stare at their mobile phones constantly are missing out because the world is quite interesting. Last year a survey found that the average Briton looks at their phone 28 times a day.  Speaking to the Daily Mirror's First Time Dads podcast earlier this year, the author said she believes all children just want to read and listen to stories - despite the dferences between le when her daughter was growing up compared to today.   Kerr said: The biggest dference I see between the children today is that they are never on their own - there is always an adult around. We used to walk everywhere and travel on the Paris  on their own. The other day I saw a group of 11 year olds on their own and it was wonderful, as you don't often see that.  I don't know whether it is fear but it is a shame. People tend to have only two children nowadays, when I was child they had five and you could manage that in the same way. Children today seem to be much more the centre of everything. Another change in the last 50 years is the increase in technology. She said: I go everywhere by Tube and everybody has got this little thing  and they are staring at it.  I look at people and find it interesting - couples to see  they are getting on, what shoes people are wearing. You are walking down the street and people are looking at this little thing so intently they almost bump into you. And I think that there could be a tiger in the street and no-one would see it except me. She said: I think some people have a rule for their children, no screens on school days which is very sensible so they can see the world. She did have a view on why it might not be the end of the world for children to look at screens not books. She said: When I was child reading was feared like screens are now - people used to say 'he always has his nose in a book' like it was a bad thing. Make sure you never miss an episode of the First Time Dads podcast.  Subscribe on iTunes Subscribe on Acast Subscribe on Spoty  Wherever you're subscribing, add a rating and review to let us know what you think. I think it is because all children really want is stories and before TV the radio and books were where you went as a child to get stories. Perhaps that is what screens give them now, it could be e-books so perhaps it's not as cut and dried as it seems.

story: NewsGirl, 4, 'excluded from school more than 10 times' despite parents saying she could have autismDaniel and Gemma Cullen believe their daughter Caoimhe may have autism and think it should have been handled betterShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAbbie Wightwick09:45, 28 SEP 2018Updated11:08, 28 SEP 2018NewsCaoimhe Cullen, four, may have autism and is waiting for a formal diagnosis "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOutraged parents of a four-year-old pupil claim she has been excluded more than 10 times in just over a year. Daniel and Gemma Cullen, from Rhondda in Wales believe their daughter Caoimhe may have autism and say she is waiting for a formal diagnosis. The pair say she was excluded more than 10 times in just over a year at Tylorstown Primary in Rhonnda Cynon Taf between April 2017 and July 2018, reports Wales Online . The disruption meant Gemma had to leave her job at a nursery. Now in her second year at school, Caoimhe attends one day a week and spends the other four days a week at a special educational needs class at Cwm Clydach Primary. Calling for better understanding of autism and possible autism among teachers and schools, Gemma said Caoimhe has never been allowed to take part in a school play and has been kept indoors at play-time at Tylorstown Primary. “She was suspended around times of school trips or extra curricular activities and during the National Tests,” said Gemma.  “She has had two five-day suspensions for kicking someone and has had three day suspensions and half day suspensions here and there. “We think she has autism, it is some sort of additional needs, but she is still a baby.” Daniel, 32, and Gemma, 29, say she has not yet had a statement of special educational needs, although they believe she has autism and/or other SENs. “We pushed and pushed for an educational psychologist evaluation which concluded that Caoimhe has a lot of autistic traits and is seriously sensory overwhelmed  in school where she can’t cope and recommended four day placement in a dferent, calmer setting,” her mum said. “We have contacted the GP and health visitor for referral to the neurodevelopment team [at hospital in Merthyr] and are still on the waiting list for an appointment. I would like some sort of help. “This has been so disruptive I had to leave my job because the school were phoning me every day to come and get her. I was a senior educator in a nursery, in Porth.” Gemma said she filed a complaint to the pupil discipline and exclusions committee of the governing body of Tylorstown Primary School after her daughter was excluded for five days last term. The committee, in July, upheld that exclusion but found procedures were not followed for one exclusion in 2017.  In a letter to her, dated July 10 this year, a support officer for the governors said: ”The committee considered the decision made by Mrs Tuck to exclude your daughter Caoimhe, for a five day period on 15th June 2018 and, after carefully considering the representations made and all the available evidence, have decided to uphold this exclusion. “The reasons for the committee’s decision are as follows: Members felt that the exclusion was warranted due to the fact that it was in response to serious breaches of the school’s behaviour policy and by allowing Caoimhe to stay in school would seriously harm the education/welfare of her or others in the school. “The Committee will investigate the information you were given as there seems to be some discrepancy with that and advice provided to the headteacher... “...In relation to the alleged unlawful exclusion in October 2017  governors agree that the guidance was not followed. This was acknowledged by the headteacher at the meeting.” The letter goes on to say: “The committee felt the support and level of graduated response that has been put in place by the school over a long period of time for Caoimhe and, plans for her future via a four day placement in the Nurture Class in Cwmclydach Primary School were sufficient, and hope that she settles in well. Because the five-day exclusion in June was a fixed term exclusion of less than 15 days, the Cullens were told they had no right of appeal against it. Meleri Thomas, from National Autistic Society Cymru , said: Around 1 in 100 children are on the autism spectrum. Every autistic child is dferent but many become overwhelmed in school – by the bright lights, loud noises or other children's unpredictable behaviour. This can result in autistic pupils behaving in ways that seem naughty or disruptive to others when actually they are overwhelmed or distressed. And they can end up being unfairly excluded.
