title: mr loophole nick freemans celebrity
story: News'Mr Loophole' Nick Freeman's celebrity drivers he's defended in court - the winners and the losersNick Freeman has built a reputation defending the likes of Sir Alex Ferguson, Sarah Harding, Freddie Flintoff, Jeremy Clarkson, Caprice and Paddy McGuinnessShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmber Hicks13:26, 28 SEP 2018NewsThe legal eagle has quite the reputation "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHe reckons he's the most famous solicitor in the country and has made millions by successfully defending a string of famous faces. But silver-tongued legal eagle Nick Freeman - aka 'Mr Loophole' - may never have stepped foot in a courtroom  it hadn't for a conversation in which he was persuaded to study law rather than become a professional golfer. Over the years he has had some stunning successes as well as fails for the famous faces he represents, including Sir Alex Ferguson, Sarah Harding, Freddie Flintoff, Jeremy Clarkson, Caprice and Paddy McGuinness.  This week, the father-of-two, who also campaigns to save Staffordshire Bull Terriers, hit the headlines when he had David Beckham's speeding conviction thrown out - thanks to a technicality.  The former footballer, 43, was accused of driving his loaned &pound200,000 Bentley at 59mph in a 40mph zone on the A40 in London's Paddington just after 5.30pm on January 23.  However, tenacious Mr Freeman, 62, managed to have the trial thrown out because the notice of intended prosecution arrived one day outside the statutory 14-day window.  And it's not the first time Manchester-based Mr Freeman has successfully defended Beckham .  In 1999 he helped overturn Becks' eight-month driving disqualication after the former Manchester United star was caught driving his Ferrari at 76 mph in a 50 mph zone. Mr Freeman claimed petried Becks was fleeing the paparazzi for ten miles through Cheshire. After that, his courtroom skills soon brought him to the attention of celebrity clients, including Jimmy Carr, Charlotte Crosby and Dwight Yorke.  He is rumoured to be Britain's highest paid lawyer, reportedly charging &pound10,000 a day in some instances, and is famed for using technicalities and highlighting procedural errors that force magistrates to throw cases out. Mr Freeman, who runs his own business, graduated from Chester Law School in 1979 and then became a prosecutor for Greater Manchester Police. He used his forensic knowledge of the Road Traffic Act to defend motorists and - ironically - became the scourge of police. Here are some of the celebrities he has represented in court - the winners and losers. The winners Sir Alex Ferguson When Sir Alex Ferguson was caught avoiding a traffic jam by driving down the hard shoulder of a motorway in 1999, Mr Freeman successfully argued Fergie had no choice because he had severe diarrhoea and was rushing to get to the toilet at United’s training ground. Fergie was followed by a police vehicle, stopped and cautioned. He told the court that he was too embarrassed to explain his predicament to the police officer. And Mr Freeman described the situation as an emergency. The former football manager, now 76, was cleared and found not guilty of illegally driving.  Andrew 'Freddie' Flintoff In 2007, ex-cricket star Andrew 'Freddie' Flintoff was accused of driving at 87mph in a temporary 50mph zone on the M62. Mr Freeman pointed out the documents were sent out 16 days after the alleged offence – and the law says the paperwork should be given to the defendant within two weeks. The 40-year-old father-of-three was cleared of speeding as a result. Speaking outside court, Mr Freeman said at the time: It is fundamental in any speeding case that the notice is sent and received within 14 days.  Jeremy Clarkson Top Gear presenter Jeremy Clarkson was charged with speeding at 82mph in a 50mph zone in Ruislip, west London in 2006. But Mr Freeman had the case dropped within minutes. He successfully argued the offending Alfa Romeo had been loaned by the car company and that any of the Top Gear team could have been at the wheel. There was no proof it was Clarkson driving and he was cleared.  Dwight Yorke Yorke, who was playing for Sunderland at the time, was spared a driving ban after pleading guilty to speeding at 85mph. The then 36-year-old had been ing home from a holiday on 8 July 2007 when he was stopped in his car on the A179 in Hartlepool. He refused to sign a police officer's form and the case was brought to court. Mr Freeman said his client had disagreed with the initial 95mph speed suggested by the officer. He said this is why Yorke, father to Katie Price's son Harvey, had not signed the documentation at the time. However, he added that the footballer accepted he had been travelling faster than the road's 70mph speed limit and asked the court to take into consideration his guilty plea for the 85mph charge. The judge fined Yorke &pound315 and gave him three penalty points.  Jimmy Carr Comedian Jimmy Carr was cleared of using a mobile phone whilst driving in 2008. Mr Freeman stated his client wasn’t making a call, but using the device to record a joke. An officer in a marked police patrol car stopped Carr, who was driving his Bentley Continental on the Hampstead Road, Harrow, on January 28, for talking into his iPhone and touching the screen. Mr Freeman argued that his client had not been using the Apple mobile phone to make a call, or for any other interactive purpose, and therefore he didn’t fall foul of this legislation. Speaking after the hearing, Mr Freeman said: “Whenever my client thinks of a joke while driving he uses his iPhone in dictation mode. “Because it was in this particular mode, and not in an interactive one, I pointed out that he hadn’t committed an offence contrary to this legislation.” The case was dismissed after a submission by Mr Freeman of “no case to answer” and Mr Carr was awarded costs from Central Funds.  Ian Brown Stone Roses lead singer Ian Brown escaped with his driving licence intact after being clocked doing 105mph on the M6 after being followed by a police car in 2011. Mr Freeman persuaded the court not to disqualy his client, so that he could continue to pick his son up from school and go to the supermarket for his elderly parents. Mr Freeman added: As somebody who is now in the public eye, one can imagine the dficulties he would now encounter  he were forced to rely on public transport. It would be literally insurmountable. Brown initially denied he had been travelling at such a speed, but later pleaded guilty. The court fined Brown &pound650 and gave him six penalty points on his licence.  Paddy McGuinness Paddy McGuinness escaped a driving ban with the help of lawyer Mr Freeman despite the TV comic earlier pleading guilty. The Take Me Out star had originally admitted a charge of failing to give information relating to the identication of a driver in 2017. It came after his Range Rover was caught speeding in August last year and carries six penalty points, which would have taken Mr McGuinness to 12 - and a mandatory ban. But between entering a plea and sentencing, he sought legal advice from Mr Freeman, who told him to withdraw the plea and go to trial. Mr Freeman said that his client had moved house three times in two years and had not received either a notice of intended prosecution or a reminder. He had only become aware of the case after receiving a single justice procedure notice  and asked for a photo of the car speeding, which it was said he also never received. The case was dismissed. Speaking after the hearing Mr Freeman said: “Mr McGuinness’s Range Rover was caught speeding on August 8, 2016, but my client did not believe he was the driver, as his car was having some work undertaken at about that time. “Mr McGuinness did not receive the notice of intended prosecution, nor the reminder, that were both allegedly sent to his home address. “My client is obviously relieved to have been found not guilty.  The losers Caprice Bourret Model Caprice Bourret was banned for driving for a year and ordered to pay &pound3,500 after admitting to drink-driving in 2005. A court heard that she had drunk two bottles of red wine and eaten only a salad when she was arrested after police saw her Mercedes had a defective fog light. At an earlier hearing the model had pleaded guilty to drink-driving. Mr Freeman argued that she should escape a driving ban because the alcohol in her blood had not left her system as quickly as normal because she had taken prescription medication for cystitis. But District Judge Emma Arbuthnot at Highbury Corner magistrates' court dismissed her claim. Mr Freeman said his client had not given police the intimate details at the time because she feared they would be leaked to the press. He had earlier told the court that the model had been given 20 antibiotics pills to fight her infection and that she had been taking them for five days before her arrest. Mr Freeman said: She believed that the alcohol would have more or less dissipated. She felt more or less all right.  Barbara Knox Coronation Street star Barbara Knox was banned from the road after turning up at a police station ‘intoxicated’ to see her daughter who had also been arrested for drink driving. The 84-year-old, who plays much-loved Rita Tanner in the soap, had seen her daughter Maxine Ashcroft taken into custody after the pair were pulled over in Knutsford on March 10, 2014. And Knox was ‘emotional’ and ‘slurring her words’ as she arrived at Knutsford Police Station later that evening, a court heard. She was carrying a set of car keys and suspecting she had driven there, police warned her not to drive again as she may be arrested. They even offered the actress, who has been in ITV show for more than four decades, a lt home, Jonathan Egan prosecuting said, however she declined. Officers then followed her to the car park and saw her get into a Jaguar and begin reversing out of a bay, the court was told. Officers found she had 85mg of alcohol in 100ml of blood, narrowly over the limit of 80. She was banned from the road for a year and fined &pound3,000. Mr Freeman told the court: “Drink driving is a serious offence and she in no way seeks to justy or condone her terrible error of judgement. “In many ways she was the author of her own misfortune. “This was an unnecessary offence.  Sarah Harding Girls Aloud star Sarah Harding said she had learned her lesson after being banned from driving for six months for using her mobile phone while driving. The singer was on her phone while at the wheel of her silver Range Rover in April 2013 in central London but refused to pull over when an officer on a bicycle tried to flag her down. Mr Freeman told the court Hardy had just signed up to be a charity ambassador and that a driving ban would hamper her ability to undertake the role. He added: She was part of a girl group called Girls Aloud and she is on the threshold of a new solo career. She would find it impossible to travel in public transport, she would be constantly harangued. But District Judge Nina Tempia said: Mr Freeman is asking the court to deal with you as opposed to a normal person but you are a normal person as far as the court is concerned. She ordered Harding to pay a &pound500 fine, plus a costs order of &pound85 and a victim surcharge of &pound20 for talking on her mobile phone while driving. A second charge of failing to stop for police was dropped.  Charlotte Crosby Reality TV star Charlotte Crosby was found guilty of drink driving in 2016. The Geordie Shore star was handed a three-year driving ban after being caught more than twice the legal limit during a drive in Newcastle. Crosby was also ordered to pay court costs of &pound1,185 while appearing in Newcastle Magistrate's Court. Her lawyer Mr Freeman told the court the star had originally planned to get a taxi for her journey from the railway station to her hotel, but instead decided to drive. She was pulled over by two police officers after they witnessed her 'weaving down the road' and was subsequently found to be twice over the legal limit. At the time, Mr Freeman said Charlotte accepts that she is the author of her misfortune while adding that she is: Bitterly ashamed, contrite and embarrassed.  His daughter - Sophie Freeman In 2010, Mr Freeman refused to defend his own daughter, Sophie, after she she had been slapped with a speeding ticket. He said he wanted the then 19-year-old to learn her lesson from the punishment. At the time he said: Mr Loophole the lawyer was in conflict with Mr Loophole the dad. Every fibre of my parental instinct told me that Sophie had to understand the consequences of breaking the law and that speeding can be a serious and dangerous issue. I'm a hypocrite. I know. His daughter was driving back from the family's apartment in North Wales when she was clocked doing 63mph in a temporary 50mph zone. She was driving a Mini Cabriolet registered to her father's law firm. A letter arrived at the company's offices days later stating that its driver faced a &pound60 fine and three licence points.  Mr Loophole himself In 2012 Mr Freeman was fined &pound60 after failing to renew his MOT on his &pound200k Bentley Azure. After being stopped on the M1 near Milton Keynes he said: “The grinning copper, chuffed at netting such a prize catch, informed me that I wasn’t under arrest but that my MoT had expired.” He said he did not book a test as he did not get a reminder letter from his garage Mr Freeman said he had called his Bentley garage in the summer asking them to let him know when his MoT was due. He added: “In fact as I explained all this to the police officer who stopped me, I rang the garage there and then to find out what had happened. They told me a letter had gone to my office in October. However, clearly it was never received and got 'lost in the post'. But because I hadn’t had a reminder, I hadn’t done anything about the MOT.”

to get at.“It’s so dficult but being a Dundee fan and seeing things the way I have over the years, I know there is nothing that should allow this club to say no.“Everyone pulling together, the office staff, kitchen staff, the youth boys, everyone, just keep smiling, keep plugging away and it’s going to turn, I’m positive of that.”Honest as ever, Kerr admits this season just plainly hasn’t been good enough from Dundee.“If you let things get out of hand it’s like a disease that spreads,” he added.“It’s all confidence-related and, as the manager spoke about before, we just need a goal to get us in front.“However, at the same time,  we are going behind in games, we can show resilience that we don’t lie down but fight for every ball, every tackle, everything we have in us, we keep fighting to the end. We just seem to be falling short just now and it’s not good enough.“There’s nothing else for it, it’s the same old cliched stuff – you’ve just go to keep fighting away.“You need to be ready to go on the training field, pushing yourself to the max every day.“We have to put in the hard yards and that’s the only way it will turn.“I know the fans and everyone at the club is frustrated, they’re obviously used to seeing better times than this, but there is still time to get our season going.“That’s the only positive – there’s another game in a few days’ time, a massive game against Hamilton and we’ve got to go and make sure we get a victory.“I know, it’s easy saying that and the punters will be sick to the back teeth of people saying ‘next week, next week’ but it’s the only thing for it.”Hamilton against Dundee has been a grudge match over the past few years and last season at New Douglas Park was one of the stand-out moments for the Dark Blues as they came from behind to win the game in the 97th-minute through A-Jay Leitch-Smith.Kerr added: “Last season at Hamilton was amazing, an incredible finish to the game and that again was a resilient performance full of character within the group.“It’s dficult being positive after Saturday’s defeat and having no points from the first six games but we have to go there, knowing how hard it is down there, it’s an absolute dogfight.“They got a great result last week but it’s a game of football, 90 minutes, and  we get ourselves on top we can win the game on Saturday.”

title: exclusive argentina legend claudio caniggia to return to dundee
story: Dundee fans haven’t had much to cheer recently but they will be given a lt with news Claudio Caniggia is set to make a  to the city.The 50-times capped Argentine international – and former strike-partner of Diego Maradona – will be back in Dundee at the Whitehall Theatre on Thursday November 29.Caniggia will be joined on stage by renowned Dundee-supporting journalists Patrick Barclay and Alan Patullo, to discuss his World Cup heroics, that goal against Brazil, his time in Italian football, being offered the chance to  to the national team at 43 years of age, and, of course, his time with the Dark Blues.His arrival at Dens Park 18 years ago, stunned Scottish football and attracted international media attention.Although 33-years-old when he signed for Ivano Bonetti’s Dundee in September 2000, a debut goal at Pittodrie proved there was no doubt that he would still be a star in the Scottish game.Despite being at Dens for less than a season, Caniggia remains idolised by the Dundee supporters and was inducted in to the Club’s Hall of Fame in 2009.The evening will be hosted by broadcaster David Tanner.During his time at Dens, Caniggia wore the No 33 shirt each time he played. Accordingly, tickets for the event are priced at £33.Tickets – including a limited number of VIP Meet &amp Greet briefs – are on sale from 9am tomorrow morning by logging on to thelongestforty.&nbspHelp For Kids are the event charity partner, with a donation being made to the charity for the benefit of local children, and tickets being made available for families who might not have otherwise been able to attend.

title: former dundee man steven caulker eyes wigan athletic deal
story: Former Dundee defender Steven Caulker is hoping to win a deal with Wigan Athletic just weeks after triggering a release clause at Dens.The 26-year-old still had a year left on his contract with the Dark Blues when he left on deadline day.It came just four months after the club had reportedly rejected a seven-figure offer from Rosenborg for the former England international.Caulker was a marquee signing for Neil McCann when he penned an 18-month contract with Dundee in January.Now he is training with Championship side Wigan ahead of a potential deal.Latics boss Paul Cook will run the rule over Caulker before deciding  he’s worth having on board.Aston Villa are also looking for a central defender and have been linked with the big centre-half, who earlier this month was reportedly training with Ukrainian Premier League Arsenal Kiev, managed by Fabrizio Ravanelli.

title: george cran dundee can get out of this mess theyve done it before
story: On the whole, no points by this stage of the season brings about relegation. Dundee will be hoping they can buck the trend – and they do have some form for it.Try to recall horric starts in the top flight for clubs – St Mirren in 2014, Livingston in 2005, Hamilton 1989, Dumbarton 1984 and Morton 1987 – and they all end in the same horror show of the drop.In 2014, the Buddies had to wait till their sixth game before picking up points, ending in bottom spot with 30 points. Post-administration Livingston took a massive 15 games to get a victory in 2005 with just one point from their first seven.You get the idea.For the Dark Blues, though, there is a small chink of sunshine, a ray of hope for the most optimistic fans to cling on to despite having no points from the first six games.The ‘12th team’ season was a poor one, of course, with plenty of reasons behind a dreadful start.A side built to get promotion from the First Division was suddenly parachuted into the top flight as Rangers were booted out.And Barry Smith’s side struggled badly. However, by this point, even they had four points from their first six games.Overall, though, nine losses in 11 games was a recipe for disaster and ended with relegation in bottom spot with 30 points.Head back to 1993 and Simon Stainrod’s final few games in charge tell a similar story to Dundee’s current predicament.No wins to their name, two draws however, led to Stainrod being moved from a manager role to director of football with his No 2 Jim Duffy taking over.They eventually beat Hearts on October 2, 1993, with goals from Garry Paterson and Dragutin Ristic.In the first of his three spells as gaffer at Dens, Duffy as player-manager couldn’t keep the Dark Blues from finishing in bottom spot – a side that eventually included a very young Neil McCann.However, head back to the early 80s and a spell where Dundee were perennially bad starters to seasons.Starting in 1980/81, Donald Mackay’s Dark Blues certainly weren’t early risers.In the First Division, that season saw no wins in the opening seven matches with two 0-0 draws at least putting something on the board.Remarkably, they didn’t manage to score a single goal in the league until the fth game.Brian Scrimgeour broke that duck in a 2-1 defeat at Hibs before they finally managed a victory at the eighth time of asking.That saw Eric Sinclair grab two along with goals from John Fletcher and Peter Mackie in a 4-0 success over Falkirk.Fast forward to the end of the campaign and that sluggish start didn’t hurt too much as Mackay’s men won promotion to the top flight, finishing second to Hibs, scoring 64 goals on the way.Two campaigns later and it was a similar story to today.The Dark Blues were yet to pick up a victory in the Premier Division by October 1 in 1983/84.At that time, there had only been five league games by that point with a League Cup group stage taking up the early fixtures.Only a 0-0 draw with St Mirren gave them anything before two own goals from Motherwell got them up and running.Eventually, Mackay’s reign came to an end in December of that year.In his place came Archie Knox to keep them in the ision, finishing four points ahead of St Johnstone.Signings like John Brown and Robert Connor saw Knox transform the Dark Blues into a solid mid-table outfit before Jocky Scott took over for the first time in 1986 and continued that.Dundee have history of getting themselves out of bad starts – whether they stick like they did with Mackay or twist with someone like Knox, they have previous.

title: hamilton boss martin canning wont be shed a tear for under pressure dundee counterpart neil mccann
story: Hamilton boss Martin Canning insists he cannot afford to take any notice of Neil McCann’s plight ahead of Saturday’s clash with bottom side Dundee.Pressure is piling on the Dens Park manager after six straight Ladbrokes Premiership defeats and a Betfred Cup exit to Ayr United.However, Canning noted his side beat St Mirren 3-0 at home on Saturday for their first win in four matches, to give Accies some respite of their own.He said: “You’ve got to go and do your own job and my job on Saturday is to try to get Hamilton Accies three points and  we can do that we’ll be delighted.“That’s just football. We know Dundee will be desperate for the points.“We’ve got to make sure we match that and that gives us the best opportunity.“We’re all going to have spells when things don’t go our way.“I’m pretty sure, same as I do, he’ll believe in his players that they can go and win games and he’ll work hard to try to make that happen.“One result can make you feel a lot better.“I think at times last season, half-a-dozen clubs went through runs of losing four, five, six games and it can happen in this league quite easily.“I thought Dundee were good against St Mirren – very good.“The goalkeeper makes a mistake and they lose the game and from there it snowballs into a poor run of results, so it can happen so easily.“The flip side of it is, you go and win two or three games in a row and it’s a completely dferent complexion.”

title: locals put up posters in bid to stop revellers using dundee close as a toilet
story: Posters have been put up at a block of flats in a bid to stop revellers urinating in the stairwell on the way back from nightspots.The flyers have appeared at a block of flats on St Andrews Street in the city centre.One resident said that there have been issues with people using the area as a toilet after leaving pubs and clubs.Posters warning that “peeing in someone’s property is punishable by law” have now appeared in the block of flats.It shows a man urinating and tells people to “please respect the residents of this house”.Maryfield councillor Georgia Cruickshank says she admires the initiative used in attempt to curb the “disgusting” behaviour, but said additional public toilets may go some way to tackling the issue.She said: “I am aware that these types of issues can happen from time to time.“It is unacceptable that tenants are having to put up with this type of thing.“Good on whoever has decided to create these posters.“I certainly wouldn’t want this type of thing happening on my front door.“There is a lot of nightle in the area, but in no way is that an excuse to use a resident’s close in this fashion.”Ms Cruickshank said that with the arrival of extra visitors to the city, there is perhaps a greater need for more public toilets with the additional boost to the day-time and night-time economy.She added: “There maybe is a call to review the amount of public toilets that are accessible after closing time.”One resident said that there has been an ongoing issue with people urinating in the close.She said: “On occasions it can smell really bad. In the past some people in the block have had to clean up.“It isn’t the responsibility of the letting agent.”Police can issue anyone caught urinating or defecating in a place that causes annoyance to others with an on-the-spot fine of £50.

title: neil mccann urges his dundee players to give themselves an easier ride
story: Neil McCann has urged his players to “give themselves an easier ride” at Hamilton on Saturday as they search for a first result of the campaign.The Dark Blues have endured a woeful start to the Premiership season, losing their opening six fixtures and scoring just twice.At the start of that run was also a 3-0 home defeat in the Betfred Cup to Ayr United, making it seven defeats on the trot.In none of those matches have Dundee managed to put themselves in front and their gaffer is desperate for the players to at least give themselves a chance of picking up a result.In order to do that, they’ll have to get the better of an Accies side high on confidence after a 3-0 thumping of St Mirren in match that has had a bit of extra spice over the past few years.And despite extra pressure on him to get the result, Neil still has faith in his side.He said: “It’s a huge game, they always have been against Hamilton.“The games against Livingston, Hamilton, Kilmarnock are going to be so important and then Hibs and Hearts.“We are still striving for that first win and we’ll keep trying to give everything to get ourselves that first goal that can at least put ourselves in a position to go and get that first win.“I still think that you could see in the first 45 minutes last Saturday, there is a team there.“I would just love to see them give themselves an easier ride by putting themselves in front.”The Dens gaffer is also hopeful of having some extra bodies back fit after a punishing injury-hit spell.Josh Meekings, Genseric Kusunga, Nathan Ralph and Sofien Moussa all missed the defeat to Hibs with injury while Kenny Miller was suspended.He’ll also miss Saturday’s trip to Hamilton while Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all added to the injury worries last weekend.The good news is winger Roarie Deacon is nearing a  after getting 45 minutes under his belt in a bounce game this week.Neil added: “We’ve not had an easy run of it and it’s been tough to get a settled side out.“We had Glen Kamara and Ryan Inniss back from injury lay-offs on Saturday but it’s been problematic in terms of that.“I have been happy with the squad,  I can get them all fit it would be welcome but we’ve not been able to get that.”

title: we are not manchester city csaba explains why he feels being dundee united boss is the hardest job in scottish football
story: There were some cursory glances around the Press room at the Falkirk Stadium after Dundee United’s 2-0 win on Saturday when boss Csaba Laszlo, almost out of nowhere, asserted the following.“The most dficult job in the Scottish Championship, or Scottish football at the moment, is to be the manager of Dundee United.”He qualied that statement by adding that it is also dficult for his players to pull on the black and tangerine but his remarks did pique the interests of those gathered.It wasn’t so much disagreement or astonishment that filled the room but more a sense of being taken aback by the brutal honesty of a man who has been under such pressure of late.He eased some of the weight on his shoulders with the result at Falkirk under what were strange circumstances – namely going up against predecessor Ray McKinnon in the opposite dugout for a side sitting bottom and pointless.And it was clear that, despite assertions by some that Csaba is daft or clueless, he was very aware of the ramications had he not got the right result.“We showed good team spirit under pressure, they handled it positively,” Csaba commented as he laid out his case to the gathered press.“Now we can close this chapter and look ahead to the next game which will be very dficult.“This is the third season where the fans have been disappointed to be in the second tier and we are talking about a very massive, strong and passionate club that wants to be in Premiership.“If something doesn’t go right immediately you have noise which is OK but we don’t want to hide behind anything.“We have this pressure and we have to accept.“We don’t want to spend one more year in the Championship – it’s not good.“The Dundee United fans don’t want to hear that from the board, the manager or anybody. They want to have the target of promotion and winning the league.“This is pressure, this is normal but you have to understand we have a budget that isn’t any higher than other teams in the main.“You have to bring a team together. We had 19 players leave and 16 players come in for the new season.“We can’t click our fingers and have the team work fantastically.“There are rules at the club about how many or which kind of players we can bring in within our budget.“It is not easy, we are not Manchester City with an owner behind you who can give you £20 million to go and spend.“We have to work with the budget we have to get the best for the club.“The Dundee United board have done a fantastic job. It is not easy to convince players from abroad to come to the Scottish Championship with everything else around.”It was quite a defence – but probably one that was coming after weeks of trying to keep a lid on it following poor results against Alloa and Morton.Yes, he has not had his troubles to seek with injury and scrutiny from all angles but it seems to be just the beginning for Csaba in his most tough of jobs.In the next four weeks they take on title rivals Ross County, Ayr United, Partick Thistle and Inverness. They kick off that run at home to County on Saturday.“I don’t just look at one game being more important than the other because you can’t afford to take any game lightly,” Csaba added. “You have to take every opponent seriously, whether they be at the top, middle or bottom of the league.”

title: Blainie 9 defies the odds in charity race
story: &nbsp&nbspIn 2016, Blainie White  was diagnosed with a form of Batten disease which affects just eight people in the UK. It is a neurological condition which causes gradual loss of sight and movement, leaving the schoolgirl wheelchair-bound.The condition also causes Blainie to suffer from epilepsy.However, a team of dedicated family and friends have rallied round to raise money for specialist equipment which could transform her quality of le, and helped Blainie complete the Baxters River Ness 5KM race last Sunday.Her proud dad Scott  said: &ldquoThere was a full squad of us out doing the run and that was fantastic. It was really good for Blainie to be able to do it.&ldquoShe was really enjoying all the noise and the music. You would never have thought that she would be able to do it, but she did.&ldquoWe have raised nearly &pound700 just through doing the run, which is brilliant.The family are raising money for a flotation device which will allow Blainie to swim, as well as a robust wheelchair to help her enjoy the great outdoors.&ldquoShe just loves going in the pool, Mr White said.&ldquoHowever, it' between &pound700 and &pound800 for a device.&ldquoWe are also looking at getting another wheelchair as well because we need one that' a bit bigger for when she' outside school.&ldquoWe are always out doing walks which is another reason we need a more robust wheelchair for her.&ldquoGetting out and about in the fresh air is something she really enjoys, but it also helps with her condition because it tires her out.&ldquoSleep is so important because  she doesn&rsquot get enough, that heightens the seizures.Blainie' cause is also being championed by the Royal Bank of Scotland, where three relatives work.The bank' staff in Inverness have picked the Batten Disease Family Association as their chosen charity for next year.&ldquoRBS have taken BDFA on as their charity of the year which is absolutely fantastic, Mr White added.&ldquoMy partner Laura and her sister both work at the bank and her other sister is the manager so I just kept pestering them. Every year they have a charity they pick and for them to pick the BDFA is brilliant.&ldquoAny money RBS raised will be doubled by the bank as well which is a huge bonus for us We are really grateful.Mr White says his daughter continues to inspire the family on a daily basis.&ldquoShe can&rsquot walk or talk any more, but she is always laughing and giggling, he said.&ldquoShe does get a lot out of le. She' an inspiration to us all.- To donate to Blainie' fund, visit justgiving/crowdfunding/littlebeesbattleFriday 28 Sep 2018 6:35 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Entrance to Victorian Market to get facelift
story: WORK&nbspcould begin on the Victorian Market' makeover as early as January.Highland Council has submitted planning applications to improve the appearance of the Academy Street entrance to the complex, which dates back to 1869.The plans involve bringing the glazed screen closer to the street in order to improve visibility into the market.The local authority says this will make the site more accessible, as well as improving security by reducing the number of access points on Academy Street to one.An uplighting system is also set to be installed in order to highlight the historic architecture of the building, and signage will be removed to &ldquo historic integrity to the Academy Street facade.The project marks the first stage of an action plan, which is being implemented by the council and the Inverness Common Good Fund, which is also set to build a business case for the remodelling of the market hall.No timescale for the completion of the work has yet been finalised, but an application for a grant of &pound30,250 has been submitted to the Inverness Townscape Heritage project.The news of the redevelopment came just days after traders in the Queensgate Arcade section of the market spoke of their struggle to deal with ongoing issues with the complex roof.Businesses in the privately-owned section of the building have been forced to take action to deal with repeated leaks which have at times forced them to close.Toni Rutherford, of the Little Teapot cafe, believes businesses in the market need help to deal with the problem.&ldquoIt is really frustrating for us that this problem keeps reappearing, she said.&ldquoIt' not good, especially when you walk into the arcade and see all the buckets.&ldquoIt' not a good impression for customers.&ldquoWe understand that there will be issues with the age of the building but that' all the more reason to take care of it, especially  people are wanting to make all these improvements to the building.&ldquoThree quarters of the building is owned by the council but the section we are in is privately owned.&ldquoThat means that any issues with the roof in our section have to be dealt with by us as traders.&ldquoThere have been times where we have had to close because of it. We have had waterfalls coming into the tearoom while customers have been in.&ldquoAlthough dferent sections of the building are owned by dferent people we are all under one roof, so we feel there should be some help available for the situation.&ldquoEveryone in the building needs to come together to get the problem solved.Friday 28 Sep 2018 6:35 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Gay pride march to go ahead
story: &nbspA gay pride march through the centre of Inverness has been given the go-ahead.Proud Ness, which will take place on October 6, has been at the centre of a bitter row after Donald Morrison, a home mission worker with the Free Church of Scotland , submitted a petition to Highland Council signed by 600 people opposing the event on "biblical, religious and moral grounds".In response, thousands of supporters signed counter petitions, saying gay pride was celebrated all over the world and the people of Inverness wanted to be on the right side of history.The council confirmed this morning the march can go ahead."We have notied the organisers that Highland Council and Police Scotland have no objections to the march being held as per the details in their notice of intention," the spokeswoman said.Previously, the spokeswoman said the petitions from both sides would not have a bearing on the decision process as the raised matters of concern were not sufficient reason to refuse the parade.Friday 28 Sep 2018 6:35 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Horror over plan for hundreds of trucks to pass Inverness school
story: &nbsp&nbspThe six-month operation, which is due to begin next spring, would take the lorries via Cloverfield Road, the southern distributor route, B8082 and onto the A9.Contractor, forestry management company Scottish Woodlands, has told Highland Council it has reached agreement with a neighbouring farmer for a track to be upgraded to give lorries access to the woods.But local community figures say that does not address the issue of public safety.The firm says the work at Balvonie Woods is essential.Inverness South councillor Ken Gowans said: &ldquoThis involves 480 truck journeys. To put that size of truck through a residential area, past Inshes Primary, is an unacceptable risk not to mention the disruption that could cause to the community. Some of the school community were horried at the prospect.Inverness South Community council secretary Bob Roberts said: &ldquoNo matter what they do the lorries will pose problems.&ldquoI&rsquom very concerned for the pupils&rsquo safety because as well as this, at certain times of day the parking around the school is horrendous.The community council is still to formulate its official response to Highland Council.Scottish Woodlands&rsquo regional development manager Bruce Taylor said: &ldquoIt' quite early days. There&rsquoll be a consultation period from now until the end of the year and we&rsquoll look at all options.&ldquo The point is to raise the proposal into the public arena and get responses with an expectation that we would be attending community council meetings to discuss the matter.&ldquoAt the end of the day, the wood is becoming unsafe because there is wind-throw in it and we need to find a solution to it because the owner is becoming concerned that at some point somebody might get hurt by a fallen tree.Dates are still to be arranged for consultation events.Friday 28 Sep 2018 6:35 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Just get on with it Eastgate Hostel owners told
story: &nbsp&nbspPat Hayden, chairwoman of Crown and City Centre Community Council, said the owners should &ldquostart now and stop making excuses after they said they were &ldquofocusing 100 per cent on moving forward with plans to finally tackle the eyesore.Owners Imtaiz Ali and a Mr Cheng recently said they hoped a contract for demolition could be in place before the end of November, but work may not start until after the festive period to avoid inconveniencing neighbouring traders.In answer to further questions posed to them by the Courier, through agent Gary Johnston of GH Johnston Building Consultants, they also revealed more about their plans for the shop spaces and two holiday apartments set to be created when the building is restored.&ldquoMr Cheng intends to reinstate his quality food takeaway restaurant, Mr Johnston said.&ldquoThe other shop unit will be available for rent as a class one shop, restaurant, hot food takeaway or other business considered suitable in the town centre. This may require a further planning application to Highland Council.&ldquoThe holiday apartments are aimed at visitors to Inverness and the Highlands and are commensurate with similar holiday lets in the High Street.&ldquoAs the apartments will be new and with a generous floor area, they will be at the higher end of the quality lets.They owners said they would take &ldquosoundings from Inverness Business Improvement District in terms of when would be the best time to start demolition work and refused to discuss why it had taken more than 2000 days to get anything done.Mr Johnston said: &ldquoThe owners will not make any comment on the past as they are now focusing 100 per cent on moving forward to get the scaffolding off the street and starting on the rebuild.But Mrs Hayden said she wanted to see action as soon as possible and there had been enough talk in the city about moving things forward.&ldquoStart now and don&rsquot use Christmas as an excuse. Get [the scaffolding] down. Today' a lovely day to start, she said.&ldquoWe&rsquove had enough excuses &ndash I&rsquom fed up of excuses.She said that when the fire happened her grand-daughter had been an infant, adding: &ldquoThat grand-daughter is about to be seven. That puts it in perspective &ndash it' been far too long.&ldquoAction is what is needed. Never mind consulting everybody &ndash everyone in that area wants rid of the scaffolding.&ldquoDon&rsquot wait until after Christmas because then the weather will be bad and then there&rsquoll be another excuse.Friday 28 Sep 2018 6:35 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Low emission shuttle bus among greener glens ideas
story: THE development of a low-emission shuttle bus service between Inverness and Drumnadrochit are among the suggestions put forward in community-devised local energy plan.The document, which will be launched at a Green Living Day in Drumnadrochit on Saturday, also includes proposals such as the development of a community-owned solar array and the provision of advice around tarf switching.The plan, which outlines key priorities for the Drumnadrochit area in relation to energy saving, power and heat generation and transport, has been drawn up following consultation with residents and ious organisations.It has been funded with EU and Scottish Government money and its development has been led by a steering group including environmental charity, Soirbheas, Glen Urquhart Rural Community Association, the Chamber of Commerce and Glen Urquhart Community Coouncil.The launch will be among a range of activities during the Green Living Day which aims to help local residents save money, have warmer homes and be healthier.Visitors will have the chance to try an electric bike, enjoy a taster health walk or join in a children' clothing and book swap.There will also be a Dr Bike session organised in conjunction with Velocity Cafe for visitors to take their cycles for a health check and simple maintenanceHome Energy Scotland will provide advice on energy saving and there will be a display of art work created by primary school pupils on the theme of green superheroes.It will be held at Glen Urquhart Hall between 11am and 3pm.Another event, Hard To Treat Properties, will be held at the Craigmonie Centre on Wednesday October 3 from 7pm to 9pm.Moses Jenkins of Historic Environment Scotland will share his expertise on installing dferent types of insulation, glazing, draught-proofing as well as outlining other energy-saving measures.Home Energy Scotland and Resource Efficient Scotland specialists will be on hand to offer free, impartial energy efficiency advice and provide information on the latest sources of funding support.- More information can be obtained on www.soirbheas.org/green-living-eventFriday 28 Sep 2018 6:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Pensioner pleads for help with poorly cat
story: &nbspAn Inverness pensioner is appealing for help with her cat' medical treatment after discovering that her monthly pet plan does not cover the cost of an X-ray.Marie MacIver' five-year-old cat Charlie has a painful leg and needs the scan to determine what treatment can be given.However, Mrs MacIver, who relies on disability benefit, is unable to afford the X-ray, which will cost about &pound300.She has now contacted the&nbspmedia in a plea for kind-hearted Invernessians to come forward."There is no way I can afford to pay for the X-ray," she said."Since it' very dficult for me to get out, I have already had to pay for the vet to come to the house and give Charlie a medical, as well as a bottle of anti-inflammatories which cost &pound29 and did nothing."I already pay &pound10 a month for a pet plan but it doesn&rsquot seem to cover anything."I have tried everywhere to get help with the vet' bills &ndash the PDSA, RSPCA and Cats Protection, but I haven&rsquot been able to get help from anywhere."I hate to see him in pain and I think it' getting worse."It came out of the blue about a month ago, and now it is just not going away."Mrs MacIver lives alone with Charlie and says she has a special bond with her little cat."He' my companion and is often the only company I have," she said."He sleeps on my bed and follows me into the kitchen, and he seems to know not to stray too far from the house because I need him."He' really more like a dog than a cat."I try my best to take care of him but things like this are very dficult, and it is such a shame because he is a lovely little cat."I need to help Charlie get better."&nbspCan you help Mrs MacIver with the cost of Charlie' X-ray? Email us via newsdesk@spp-groupFriday 28 Sep 2018 6:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: World of work goes back to school in Inverness
story: &nbsp&nbspThe event &ndash which was supported by Highlands and Islands Airport Limited , Skills Development Scotland and Developing the Young Workforce  Inverness &amp Central Highland &ndash involved organisations across a wide range of sectors, including healthcare, education, construction, hospitality, tourism, science and technology, finance, creative industries and emergency services..The pupils also had the chance to work on their CVs, discover workplace expectations and practice their interview skills.Head teacher John Rutter said: &ldquoWe consistently have high positive destination figures for our school leavers and events such as this really complement the year-round hard work that all our staff put into giving our young people the best possible chances for success.For the first time, the event also included a mini trade show, giving pupils the chance to mingle with the more than 40 businesses attending.Andy Maxtone, programme manager for DYW Inverness &amp Central Highland, said: &ldquoInitiatives like the employability event are great for pupils, as it opens their eyes to the dferent types of jobs out there, and the ious paths that can be taken to attain them.Friday 28 Sep 2018 6:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: sign our petition to change time of aberdeen semi final clash at hampden1
story: Dons fans have branded the decision to make Aberdeen’s League Cup semi-final against Rangers at Hampden a noon kick-off “an absolute disgrace”.Supporters’ groups, the club and Hearts have all hit out after it was revealed both semi-finals would be played at the national stadium in Glasgow on the same day.And now the Evening Express has launched a petition in an effort to make the SPFL reconsider the ridiculous scheduling of the Aberdeen v Rangers League Cup semi-final on Sunday October 28.The lunchtime kick-off is an outrageous time for fans from the north-east to get to Hampden – and scheduling the Hearts v Celtic semi on the same day at the same venue only compounds the problem.Sign this petition to send a message to the SPFL that’s loud and clear: This showpiece fixture MUST be changed to a new venue or time for the sake of the fans.

title: autumn is a great time to make some home improvements
story: There’s a change in the air – the mornings are crisper and the nights are getting dark earlier. But there’s still time to get your home ready for the throes of winter.Autumn is the last chance for green-fingered gardeners to do work outside before the ground gets too hard. And with the gardening tools due to get packed away until after the new year, some people will need some new storage to house it all.Inside, the cold weather means that keep your home cosy is more important. Checking that your home is energy efficient  and that your heating systems are in good working order is the best way to avoid any unwanted problems over the winter.Here’s just a few ways you can do some home improvements this autumn. 100vw, 800px" /Many people have a shed in their garden. But how many have a summerhouse?It’s probably true to say that summerhouses are not as common an item in back gardens as sheds are.One feature that you must consider is to incorporate a summerhouse into the design of your garden, because this increases your living space and usability.A great advantage of log cabins over other garden buildings is that you can create all sorts of uses for them. Whether you’ve dreamed of owning your own studio or would love to work from home, it’s all possible with a garden log cabin.You can sit undercover and in warmth to enjoy the beauty of your garden with its wildle creatures and birds.Your new summerhouse can be a room for all the family you can enjoy living in the garden on sunny days, have a nice meal away from the television, and have the simple pleasure of each other’s company.Escape from the pressures of everyday le to your own garden haven retreat, sit in style and enjoy le’s labours at pleasure. A great place for you to hide from the family when you simply need space!If you have a smaller garden, you can use a log cabin as a general storage shed as well as your idyllic space to relax and unwind. Some log cabins come with an additional lean-to which offers the garden storage of a shed.Deeside Log Cabins has built an enviable reputation over many years, supplying and erecting everything from standard garden sheds, to large multi-room cabins, with thousands of happy customers.They can also supply cabin kits for self-build, and willingly provide advice and helpful tips to make your job easier.Find out more at the Deeside Log Cabins website. 100vw, 800px" /Still on the garden theme, why not visit Mains of Drum this autumn and view their extensive range of indoor and outdoor accessories?Based in Royal Deeside, they have received prestigious award from the Garden Centre Association . After rigorous seasonal inspections of garden centres across the UK the GCA awarded the Mains of Drum ‘Best Garden Centre in Scotland’ for the second year running.The GCA also placed the Mains of Drum in the top three for the entire UK.This is an incredible achievement for the family-run garden centre, which opened in 2009. The dedicated and highly-motivated staff at the popular garden centre are working hard to maintain and improve on the high benchmarks required by the GCA.The winner of the coveted ‘Best in UK’ will be announced in January 2019 after a final round of judging.The Mains of Drum Garden Centre also won the following categories: Customer Service, Garden Products Retailer, Indoor Lestyle and Website. In addition, the Mains of Drum are finalists in the GCA Ruxley Rose Competition for the best Plant Area in the UK the winner will be announced in January.Craig Forbes, manager said: “We are all thrilled to receive this accolade and are proud to be members of the GCA. This award recognises the hard work of all the team at the Mains of Drum over the past year. We would like to take this opportunity to thank all of our loyal customers and suppliers for their continued support.”The GCA requires all members to meet standards that represent the very best in garden centre retailing.Ensuring customer satisfaction is a crucial aspect of GCA activity. Every GCA garden centre is subjected to unannounced comprehensive inspections by independent consultants to satisfy the GCA expectation that members maintain and improve on these high standards.Visit the Mains of Drum website for more information. 100vw, 800px" /Homeowners have once again voted Thistle Windows &amp Conservatories the best in the UK for customer satisfaction – its 16th major national award from the respected industry standards organisation Independent Network.The Aberdeen-based company was named top in its class at Independent Network’s annual award ceremony and also has the honour of holding the most trophies in the entire organisation of over 140 member companies UK-wide.Managing Director Ian Bruce said: “It’s fantastic to be recognised in this way &#8211 our entire team has played an important role in maintaining a high level of satisfaction at every stage of our customers’ projects, from the initial quotation experience all the way through to efficient installation and completion.“We are also thrilled at gaining more customers than ever – while at the same time ensuring that exceptionally high levels of customer satisfaction are being delivered.”The awards are based on feedback questionnaire responses from more than 15,000 customers of all member companies of the Independent Network. Thistle came top in the highest-tier UK award category.Thistle has continued to grow and expand with a move into a 35,000 sq. ft head office, showroom and warehouse facility in the city’s Bridge of Don area. The local firm currently employs over 130 staff and is also due to open a brand-new showroom in the next few months.Find out more at the Thistle Windows &amp Conservatories website. 100vw, 540px" /For flooring solutions with the wow factor this autumn, consider the benefits of tile flooring.Available from Aberdeen Tile, porcelain tiles look and feel incredibly like real wood, making it the ideal solution for those looking to have stylish, yet practical, flooring.Owner Eric Meston explained: “They really do look like real wood and it is very dficult to tell the dference between the two.“Wooden flooring can be beautul but sometimes can be quite impractical. Whether it is cleaning, maintaining or simply being unsuitable for a given room, wooden flooring is not always the best option. Now there is a solution allowing you to have the look of real wood but without the disadvantages that go along with it – wood effect tiles.”Wood effect tiles are incredibly durable and will last a long time. They can be used near hot stoves and fireplaces and also in bathrooms and kitchens where wood and wood laminates can suffer from constant exposure to water splashes. Furthermore, they are perfect for underfloor heating.Eric adds “Porcelain tiles, once installed, will stay flat. Wood and particularly wood laminates can curl up over time, so they are perfect for use both indoors and outdoors.“But don’t forget – wooden effect tiling is not just restricted to the floor they can even be used on walls and other vertical surfaces.”Visit Aberdeen Tiles extensive showroom to meet their friendly, expert team and see the likeliness of wooden effect tiles for yourself.Find out more at the Aberdeen Tile website. 100vw, 424px" /With the darker nights approaching, now is the right time to consider a health check on your home or workplace electrics – so call the experts at SWES!Today, there are so many safety measures and checks that we undertake in day-to-day le – whether it be an MOT to ensure cars are safe to drive or an annual service on boiler and gas appliances. We even go to the expense of having private health checks on ourselves.With new legislation due to come into effect in January, the SWES team explained the importance of making sure your electrics are checked regularly.The signicant changes, naming but a few, are in the provisions for protection against fire resulting from the electrical installation, a new section to cover energy efficiency and changes to cover heating systems that are embedded.An electrical Inspection Condition Report or often called a Fixed Wiring Test is normally a relatively painless, affordable and non-invasive procedure to check your home or workplace electrics.A report will then be created to provide you a compressive description on the wiring condition and where any faults, observations are noted will be coded according to their risk factor.More commonly now insurers will ask  these checks have been made and in some cases this can result in lower premiums and provide peace of mind to home owners and employers.So this autumn, be safe and give your home an electrical MOT – guarantee peace of mind with the local, professional team at SWES.Go to the SWES website to find out more. 100vw, 620px" /Family run for over three years The Good Sleep Company, based in Banff, has gone from strength to strength delivering the north east with a good night’s sleep.Their quality range of beds, mattresses and expert advice have resulted in a good reputation for the business – and with it, many repeat customers.Owners Scott and Jill Birnie, who over 10 years’ experience in the bed industry, explained their aim: “Our beds and mattresses are all carefully selected to give you the best choice for a great night’s sleep. With expert advice, free delivery and our exclusive Good Sleep Guarantee, we’ll make sure you love what you lie in!”The Good Sleep Guarantee has proved to be an important part of the shop’s success.Scott added: “Buying a mattress can be tricky and we understand that. We will be there every step of the way to help you make the right decision but sometimes it takes time and that’s what we want to give you.“Buy your mattress from us, take it home, try it for 30 days and  you decide it really isn&#8217t for you  then we will be happy to change it for a brand new one of your choice!”The Banff showroom boasts 2000 sq ft, displaying a complete range of bed frames, mattresses, an sets and bedroom furniture will offer everything you need for a good sleep, from the best quality mattresses and furniture to a hand-selected range of coordinating linens.With an ever-growing range of complimentary furniture now available, you can choose those must-have accessories to finish off the perfect room!Open Monday to Saturday on High Street, Banff, click here to visit their Facebook page.

title: letters to the editor week 34
story: Colin CameronUpdated: 26/08/18, 9:00 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to ?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.Sir,The decision of Argyll and Bute Council to allow expansion of Poll na Gille and BDNC Loch Shuna is reprehensible.These sites have been named as being the first and third worst respectively of all the salmon farms in Scotland on an index of welfare and health measures, including premature death rates, sea lice numbers, escapes, breaches of biomass limits and seal shooting .Despite the above, there was a decision made by Argyll and Bute planning department that Environmental Impact Assessments were not required for the expansion of either of these fish farms.The Environment, Climate Change and Land Reform committee report on the environmental impacts of salmon farming stated, in a letter dated March 5, 2018, to the Rural Economy and Connectivity committee that: &#8216The committee is supportive of aquaculture, but further development and expansion must be on the basis of a precautionary approach and must be based on resolving the environmental problems.  The status quo is not an option.&#8217It is apparent that Argyll and Bute Council does not intend to adopt the precautionary approach recommended, but continues to agree to unsustainable expansion, even at locations which are in breach of the current standards required.Christine Richards, Friends of the Sound of JuraSir,We would like to invite your more adventurous readers to join us on our Lake District challenge next spring and help save lives and rebuild futures shattered by meningitis.They will conquer eight peaks, all above 3,000 feet, over two days. It will require energy, commitment and a positive attitude, but will reward those taking part with breath-taking views, wrapped up in a serious adventure and a weekend they’ll never forget – there’s a great team spirit amongst those taking part and many come away from the challenge having made lelong friends.Every step they take will also help us to fight meningitis and move us closer to our vision of a future where no one in the UK dies from this devastating disease and everyone affected gets the support they need.Registration is just £49, with a fundraising pledge of £500. Accommodation, food, travel and the support of a qualied and experienced mountain leader and safety team are all included, and I&#8217ll be there to support you throughout your fundraising journey. It takes place between Thursday May 2 and Sunday May 5 next year.Find out more at www.MeningitisNow.org or by emailing me at michaelai@meningitisnow.org .Michaela Ifill, Meningitis NowSir,The World&#8217s Biggest Coffee Morning event is fast approaching and we would love for readers in Argyll and Bute to get involved.Having become a national institution since it launched in 1990, it has raised millions to help change the lives of people living with cancer, including here in Argyll and Bute.Last year some 200,000 people said that they were planning on taking part in homes, workplaces and schools across the country &#8211 but the idea remains as simple as ever: come together as a community in support of people living with cancer and raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support.Cancer can affect every aspect of a person’s le, from their day-to-day living and relationships to their finances and mental health. Macmillan is there to help people with cancer live le as fully as they can.Offering a broad range of cancer information and support services &#8211 including a free support line and a community of over 7,700 healthcare professionals &#8211 demand for Macmillan’s services is constantly growing, but we rely on the generosity of the public to provide this support.Macmillan’s Coffee Morning takes place on Friday September 28 &#8211 but people can host whenever they want. Whoever they invite and whatever they serve, people are highly encouraged to host a Macmillan Coffee Morning in a way that suits them.If people can’t bake, that doesn’t have to stop them. Throughout September, headline partner M&ampS will be selling a selection of limited edition coffee morning products &#8211 including lots of cakes, biscuits and two exclusive mugs &#8211 with 10 per cent of proceeds going to Macmillan.Homes, workplaces and communities from the Shetland Islands to Land’s End will be hosting coffee mornings this year readers in Argyll and Bute can find events nearby using the interactive map on the Coffee Morning website www.macmillan.org.uk/coffee.Thank you to everyone who gets involved.Joanna Lumley, actress and Macmillan supporterSir,The SNP announced it is starting up a new &#8216fact-checking&#8217 service to monitor the accuracy of research and political statements.Many people in Scotland will be wondering  the SNP will be fact-checking the cost of its new independence blueprint. Analysis has continually shown that an independent Scotland would mean cuts to public spending and increased taxes.The SNP now has to answer serious questions about the real cost of independence as the latest GERS figures will once again show how much we benefit from being part of the UK. It&#8217s time for the separatists to be honest and accept the facts.With Labour embroiled in a new scandal almost every second day and the LibDems disappearing into irrelevance it&#8217s clear that only Ruth Davidson&#8217s Scottish Conservatives can stand up to Nicola Sturgeon&#8217s IndyRef2 obsession.Cllr Alastair Redman, Isle of Islay&nbsp

title: mid argyll athletics club open sports day
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated: 07/09/18, 10:03 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to ?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.Subscribe NowThe exceptionally wet weather on Sunday August 26 forced Mid Argyll Athletic club indoors to hold their annual sports day and age group championships.Fortunately both the games hall and gymnasium at Lochgilphead Joint Campus were free which ensured the competition was not cancelled and the young athletes contested a modied programme of five events in a warm and dry atmosphere.Young athletes travelled from Cowal, Kintyre, Oban and as far away as Bunessan on Mull.Arguably the top performances of the day were in a very competitive girls under 11 age group where Jemma MacDonald from Lochgilphead, Beth Johnstone from Tarbert and Kirstie Renton from Campbeltown excelled and finished with local girl Jemma winning overall. Jemma won the two-lap race in 25.7 seconds and placed highly in another three events. Beth won the high jump clearing 1.14m and the long jump and Kirstie had an outstanding run to win the four-lap race in 55.5 seconds. The other event winner in this contest was Jemma’s twin sister Jorja who won the javelin throwing 14 metres.Local girl Neve Bowden was the under 9 champion thanks to wins in the four-lap race and long jump. Scarlett Speirs from Inveraray was runner-up winning the high jump and two-lap race. Carla Renton from Campbeltown won the javelin in this age group.Violet Campbell from Glenbarr dominated in the under 13’s contest winning all five events including a 6.49 metres throw in the shot putt. Emma Plumber from Tayvallich was runner up with Kyra Robertson from Ardrishaig in third place.Karis Kidd from Ardrishaig was the under 15 champion, winning the two running events and the long jump and finished 1.5 points ahead of Amy Gibson from Bunessan on Mull who won the high jump with a 1.40 metres clearance. Caryn Kerr from Campbeltown was third on overall points and won the shot putt with a 6.67 metres throw. The previous week Caryn won the junior shot putt at Oban Highland Games.Three girls tied on points in the under 7’s competition and the final placings were decided on the most inidual wins which resulted in Cara Green from Ardrishaig the winner ahead of Zara Whyte and Chloe Hill.Ruairidh Charnock from Lochgilphead was the boys under 7 champion just one point ahead of Olly MacVicar from Tighnabruaich. Ruairidh won the two-lap race and long jump while Olly won the four-laprace and javelin throwing nine metres.Local boy George Balkeen dominated in the under 9’s with a clean sweep of wins which included impressive performances in the two-lap race recording 27.9 seconds, four-lap in 61.6 and a 10.50 metres javelin throw. Luke MacVicar from Tighnabruaich was second overall and Ciaran Johnstone from Oban was third.Roan MacVicar from Tighnabruaich was the under 11 champion thanks to wins in the two running events and finished four points ahead of Sam Gillespie from Lochgilphead who won the high jump and javelin throwing an impressive 14.25m. title: science matters week 36
story: Colin CameronUpdated: 09/09/18, 9:01 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to ?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.The multi-million dollar international trade in exotic pets has long been a bugbear of mine.Not only does it promote wild animals as  fashion accessories, but it also allows potentially dangerous microbes to jump to, and cause epidemics in, other species including humans. What’s more, even  they don’t mutate as occurred in the case outlined here,  released into the wild either by design or mistake these foreigners can cause havoc to local ecosystems.In a letter to the scientic journal Nature in 2003, a group of German scientists began ‘it has been rumoured that an unidentied crayfish…of marbled appearance and uncertain geographical origin that was introduced into the German aquarium trade in the mid 1990s, is capable of unisexual reproduction ’.The authors ended by warning that: ‘This crayfish…could become a menace to European freshwater systems, as the release of even one specimen into the wild would be enough to found a population that might out-compete native crayfish’.Now, 23 years later, this all-female crayfish has escaped into the wild.  Identied as a descendent of the fresh water slough crayfish from Florida, it is now called the marbled crayfish or Marmokrebs. So far it has invaded the waterways of at least nine European countries as well as Japan and Madagascar. Unravelling its origin reveals that a unique macro-mutation must have occurred in a single slough crayfish egg probably caused by heat or cold shock whilst in transit from Florida to Germany for the pet market.The resulting female hatchling possessed three sets of chromosomes per cell  and the ability to produce clones of itself without a mate and at very high frequency.Because of its warm climate and abundant freshwater habitats, Madagascar has seen the most rapid colonisation with Marmokrebs. Millions of the animals have invaded the countries lakes, rice paddies and swamps and are threatening its seven endemic crayfish species.It is only a matter of time before this scenario is repeated in other locations, destroying valuable ecosystems and eliminating indigenous species.

title: some close shaves in the strc
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated: 10/09/18, 9:00 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to ?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.Subscribe NowThere were only two Mid Argyll crews competing in the Scottish Tarmac Rally Championship  Pendragon stages at Warcop training camp in Cumbria on Sunday August 26.They were Donald Bowness and navigator Paul Gribben in their Vauxhall Nova and Jamie Miller and Ian McCulloch in their Citroen C2R2Max. Both crews compete in the 1600 class.This was Jamie&#8217s second outing in the car. title: letters to the editor week 37
story: Colin CameronUpdated: 16/09/18, 7:03 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to ?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.Sir,It is always a delight when a letter awakens a landowner.James F Lithgow&#8217s insult about ‘blow-ins’ is a typical trait. I worked extremely hard to buy my farm, not being able to piggyback on my forebears’ efforts, and I didn’t ‘blow-in’, it took two forty-foot pantechnicons four days.It is clear he has an interest in wind turbines, and no doubt with a pair of wellies, a fish farm or two. His blinkered refusal to accept the huge body of evidence regarding fish farm contamination suggests he has an investment and it needs protecting. But only, of course,  you don’t have a commercial interest.There is a huge amount of evidence that mechanical kelp harvesting does irreparable damage to the sea bed. Could I draw your readers&#8217 attention to the Facebook page &#8216Stop Mechanical Kelp Dredging&#8217?The sea bed can’t be seen, but a bank statement can. No prizes for who is the loser. The 600 jobs in aquaculture will not last long  mass kelp harvesting is allowed to decimate sub-sea environments and the only jobs on fish farms will be pushing barrows of diseased and dead fish.I’ve no doubt he knows that wind turbines have a 25-year le span and then the hugely disruptive process will start again  an alternative has not been discovered. It has been calculated that the energy costs of a wind turbine will never be recovered during its lespan, but those receiving grants really don’t care.Why, given the amount of rainfall in Argyll, are hydro schemes not pursued? It used to be a mystery, until one looks at the vast sums of subsidy given by a gullible government to so called ‘alternative energy sources’, which actually means ‘alternative revenue sources’.There are any number of pretty glens that could be dammed, providing an extra environmentally-friendly leisure resource, create an opportunity for aquaculture and would not require a replacement somewhere down the line.Alexander Hamilton, Tayvallich.Sir,With reference to James Lithgow’s letter of September 7, it is important to make a couple of points.Mr Lithgow is right to say kelp has been sustainably harvested in Argyll for generations. There can be no comparison, however, with the current proposal to mechanically dredge up entire stands from the seabed together with all the fragile le that depends on them. This is not sustainable as evidenced in the few countries which have allowed this practice to take place.  Seaweed cultivation, on the other hand, is sustainable and more can be found on this through the Scottish Association for Marine Science.The 2018 parliamentary inquiry into the environmental impact of salmon farming warned current methods could cause &#8216irrecoverable damage&#8217.  This is deeply concerning to those of us who live here, raise families and rely on the sea for our creel fishing, shellfish and tourism businesses. We also all have an inherent responsibility to care for our environment and there is increasing urgency to do this.Enterprises do need to be encouraged to grow and to provide opportunities and employment. This, however, must be done responsibly and with thought for the long-term viability of our communities.The profits of the predominantly multi-national salmon farming companies, who benefit from current loopholes in our environmental regulations, are well able to fund a responsible and researched approach for sustainability and erse employment opportunities. Norway, for example, is encouraging its salmon farmers to adopt closed containment and these methods are working well in a number of other countries, including the USA.The council has a legal responsibility for the environment and needs to take precautions for the future of Argyll, not just for job numbers today.If short-term interests are prioritised, all of our futures will be much the poorer.Will Self, on behalf of Friends of the Sound of JuraSir,Most schools in Scotland have pipers and drummers within their pupil population.Schools in Argyll are probably no exception. May I please ask your readers to seek out their pipers and encourage them to represent their school as a piping quartet,  not as a full band, at the next Scottish Schools Pipe Band Championships?The championships are organised annually by the Scottish Schools Pipes and Drums Trust. The next championships will be held at Inveralmond Community High School, Livingston, on Sunday March 10 2019.More details are on our website &#8211 www.thechampionships.Last March, 145 schools from Scotland and two from England were represented at the championships, with a category for all standards of playing.Five years ago we introduced a new category of &#8216freestyle&#8217.  The aim of this is to provide an opportunity for schools to showcase their other musical skills alongside those of their pipers.The Scottish Schools Pipes and Drums Trust  hopes many young pipers and drummers from Mid Argyll &#8211 with other musicians too  entering the freestyle event – will participate in next year’s championships.Patrick Gascoigne, administrator, Scottish Schools Pipe Band Championships.
